Posts.Content: user326, welcome. I concur with Highlander . Unfortunately, like probably all or at least most of us here, your biopsy is POSITIVE. It's time for action with the appropriate oncologist . A Gleason score of 3+4=7 is demanding action, Gleason 3+3=6 may result in active surveillance but you have two reported 3+4=7 , action is required. I would waste no more time thinking about it but rather get to the urologist or oncologist to discuss and begin a course of treatment. I am somewhat surprised that your URO hasn't already recommended a course of treatment. Two Gleason 7 cores are not a wait and see scenario. The good news is they are treatable , should you look backwards at many of our profiles you will see that most of us have been there done that with even higher Gleason scores. You have many good options but do not delay in a discussion for treatment . Best to you.
Posts.Signature: DOB 1948 good overall health, non smoker, non drinker. Active with physicals, colonoscopy's and PSA testing ( urologist). Over the last 10 year period my PSA has risen gradually from 1.8 to a recent 6.4 with the most drastic change over the last 18 months, 3.8 to 6.4. I also had BPH . Colonoscopy's have all been clear. Also not overweight by more than maybe 20 pounds. No other nagging health history. Biopsy 9/18/2017 12 cores, 10 negative, 2 positive #1 grade group 1 / 3+3=6 1.7 cm, 10%, involving 1 core #2 grade group 4 / 4+4=8 2 cm, 15%, involving 1 core 10 remaining cores benign RALP 11-21-17 2 nights in Hospital, no real pain, mild discomfort. Post Op Lab report everything clear Post Op PT2 score, G8 organ confined. 11 nymph nodes benign Bladder neck and surrounding tissue benign 3 months post op, 100% dry day and night ED Injections ,@ .2 TRIMIX, so far so good. Zero PSA March 1, 2018 First PSA since surgery

Posts.Title: RALP in 20 hours

Posts.Content: Welcome N.A.H, sorry to learn of your situation but it's better to learn it early, as you have done. excellent replies above. The list of questions is excellent but I do feel the Surgeon can answer many of them before you even ask them . Has he entered your specific data into the Sloan Kettering website ? A ton of fairly accurate % answers come out of that. No Surgeon can give you a 100% answer . Incontinence %, ED %,..will the cancer return % etc...I suspect once you choose a surgeon he will indeed do this. Do ask him to him show the surgical path and why , in detail, it will also prompt several questions and answers. Another valid question is, what is primary ? attacking and eliminating the possibility of cancer at the apex vs nerve sparing. The one question I did not ask, as the Surgeon addressed it before I asked , what is my life expectancy. An excellent reply would be 15 years or greater. I believe thats the extreme window for the data right now. This is the question we are all afraid to ask, he was not afraid to address it . A good surgeon will also request that you be in the best physical shape and weight that you can be at the time of Surgery . This can easily lead to a life changing diet and daily habits. As stated above, many of us have been thru this and came thru it with excellent results and recovery. It appears that you are going to be in excellent hands, trust the surgeon. In my particular case, everything that the Doc( Surgeon ) said was going to happen along with post pathology results, is exactly what happened. I happened to have good news all the way around but he was not surprised, pleased, but not surprised, it's what he expected. Stay the course wishing you the best t

Posts.Content: Winglets, When you say DR, do you mean GP or Urologist ? If it were me I would go see a Urologist where they may request an MRI. It may very well be related to other things like meds. A URO appt should take moments , not years . Typically you don't really need a referral, find out who a leading URO is in your area, call and make an appt. just make sure they are on your INS plan. Regarding prostate issues early, it's not uncommon, and for someone to say it's not a prostate issue in my mind is irresponsible. How do they know ? Remember , we are not Dr's here, unless someone says they are, we are just sharing experiences. I'm back to go see a Urologist, this is what they do. Best to you, let us know how things are going. t

Posts.Title: 1 week post robotic fun

Posts.Content: Mike, I am very much like stated above, I am now 3 weeks post surgery and 12 days post catheter. I find I am getting the urge to go every 2 to 3 hours and I am getting up around 3 times each night. I am leaking but not wetting. I can get to the toilet in time and even hold it for a brief period. period. During the day if I have too much activity I find I leak a bit more, not emptying the bladder, leaking. I still go to the toilet every couple of hours with the urge. The leaking is annoying but in the scheme of things I feel that too will improve over time. Diet, liquids , kegels, activity, etc, I am of the opinion all of that matters. The Dr's Nurse told me that the bladder is going to take some time to get back to normal, it is now resting on the rectum rather than the prostate so it knows something is different plus it just had a catheter stuck in it that it had to adjust to , now it's gone and has to adjust again. Time.... I am hopeful that I can get to 4 or 5 hours which would be great. I have lived the last last 8 years with BPH, going every 2 hours like clockwork. Anything over 2 hours would be a a huge improvement. I have my 1st POST OP appt with he Doc next week and this will be one of my questions as well as the obvious discussion.

Posts.Title: RALP...Nobody ever discussed costs ! What are they ?

Posts.Content: 7 more days, it felt like an eternity. But I'm ready, relaxed, stressed a bit, but relaxed. ready to move on. I know for me it's the right decision. This journey started well over a year ago when the very stable PSA rose from the hi 2's to the 3's then into the 4's then over 6 this past July. It was not a shock. Quite frankly I was expecting it. The Urologist who I have been seeing for a decade was never shy about using the C word over the last decade. July came , the biopsy was scheduled 5 weeks later, good grief the wait was near impossible . Then post biopsy, the call came , 2 positive spots out of 12. Certainly didn't want to hear this but it was not a shock. The conversations with the Urologist over the last couple of years prepared me for the worst case scenario. He did his job. And very well. Post Biopsy, scheduled appointment with the Surgeon, ( same office ) very detailed, very experienced, very positive , but yet held nothing back. To me this is critical , the flow of information and conversation with regard to whats ahead. No stone unturned. The doc went thru the entire procedure even showed us ( wife and I ) the surgical path, what he is going to do, where he is cutting, where he is not. Also plugged my numbers into the Sloan Kettering data base and showed us where we stand POST surgery. He answered questions I didn't even know to ask. Even those I didn't ask but wanted answers to. Life expectancy greater than 15 years better than 99% ( from this ) Cancer return possible after 10 years under 40 % from this , he believes it will be a lower % because the data base doesn't ask for the surgical path, it's just numbers. 10% incontinence possible 50% impotency possible One thing he made clear, his goal is NO CANCER, he does not spare muscle at the risk of any cancer remaining. He has done over 3000 RALP's and over 1000 non RALP. that in itself is amazing, the amount of men that go thru this. He did laugh and advised us that in 15 years I will bee seeing another Dr as he is retiring in 2 years. 15 years is a long time . I'll be right near 85, he will be 88. He did a Cystoscope during that pre-op visit, , it's terrible, 2 min of pure " I hate this". If someone says they are not that bad, they are indeed altering the truth Then the 6 week wait until surgery. just before I left the office he says..oh yeh, no more bread, pasta, potatoes, rice etc...until surgery. Drop 10 pounds please. And walk a mile a day. I'm about 15 or 20 pounds over where I should really be. So for 6 weeks, while waiting , no more of the good food I love, and yes, it looks like I dropped the 10 pounds or very close. I have been in constant communication with 2 or 3 friends who have been thru the same thing, I also stopped all Google searches as well. There is no point anymore. Other than a few visits to this forum now and then, I stay away. The folks on this forum are very positive and informative. people tell me I am very positive, I guess I am but treatment , surgery or chemo, is not a choice, it's mandatory. You can't dwell on it. We made the decision best for us, the Doc agrees and now the 6 weeks is just about here. I have 3 PRE Surgery appts today, Kegel exercises at the Hospital, then the final pre-surgery with the surgeons office, then back to the Hospital PRE OP for " how ya gonna pay for all this" . Long day, but the end is near. The only thing I want to know about now is the post surgery report. Thats where my mind is now, I'm beyond the surgery. 7 days to go.... I am still very nervous and have high anxiety. When I wake up after it's done, life will be somewhat different but my wife and I both agree that we will finally be on the other side of all of this.

Posts.Title: 7 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: It's a good question but it would be near impossible to seek an accurate answer. Every person that goes thru this does not participate on a forum for various reasons. It's kinda like asking why everyone does not have a Facebook page or why everyone does not Tweet. It does appear that the statistics on this site suggest there are more surgery members rather than radiation treatment members, but that can easily be defined as people who selected surgery are seeking information or answers. I'm one of them . There is no magic wand, but I do know that today, surgery is much more accepted than it was even 10 years ago. The procedure is now considered, as awful as this sounds, common. The idea of having cancer in our body is a tuff one to accept and my take is that if given a choice to get rid of it and deal with the after effects, far outweighs still having it in our body and trying to beat it to death over a long period of time. Another major factor to consider is, it is widely understood that once radiation treatments are selected and begin, surgery is no longer an option should things don't improve. That can be a deal killer for many people, it was for me. OF my few close friends who have had to deal with this nasty beast, the ones who selected surgery, even 10 years ago, far exceed the "cure time curve " over those who had radiation treatments. Thats not to say that everyone is equal, we are not. A very close friend who uses the same Dr's as I, it took 10 years of radiation treatments to get him to the point of "cure" . In all fairness though, he did not qualify for surgery at the time of diagnosis, his PSA was off the charts and the multiple bad cells had already left the prostate. He recently told me that if he had qualified for surgery he would have selected surgery in a NY minute. Here is the only stat I know, the surgeon that performed my operation, very well known and respected in this region, has performed approx 3000 of these operations over the last 10 years. One thing he did tell me early on, if my spots were G6, I would not have qualified for surgery. His diagnosis for my 1/G8 on the apex, was that we can kill the beast and get it out of your body before it decides to take on another path. We talked about radiation, and we could have gone that direction but once I heard what I had to do over the next several years as well as knowing that we may not beat it, the choice became obvious for both me and my wife. Especially knowing that surgery would no longer be an option. Most likely in the next 10 years PC patients will have yet another option to select, things are improving all the time. maybe in 20 years, RALP will be a thing of the past , who knows... best to you t

Posts.Title: Which treatment is most common?

Posts.Content: It's a good question but it would be near impossible to seek an accurate answer. Every person that goes thru this does not participate on a forum for various reasons. It's kinda like asking why everyone does not have a Facebook page or why everyone does not Tweet. It does appear that the statistics on this site suggest there are more surgery members rather than radiation treatment members, but that can easily be defined as people who selected surgery are seeking information or answers. I'm one of them . There is no magic wand, but I do know that today, surgery is much more accepted than it was even 10 years ago. The procedure is now considered, as awful as this sounds, common. The idea of having cancer in our body is a tuff one to accept and my take is that if given a choice to get rid of it and deal with the after effects, far outweighs still having it in our body and trying to beat it to death over a long period of time. Another major factor to consider is, it is widely understood that once radiation treatments are selected and begin, surgery is no longer an option should things don't improve. That can be a deal killer for many people, it was for me. OF my few close friends who have had to deal with this nasty beast, the ones who selected surgery, even 10 years ago, far exceed the "cure time curve " over those who had radiation treatments. Thats not to say that everyone is equal, we are not. A very close friend who uses the same Dr's as I, it took 10 years of radiation treatments to get him to the point of "cure" . In all fairness though, he did not qualify for surgery at the time of diagnosis, his PSA was off the charts and the multiple bad cells had already left the prostate. He recently told me that if he had qualified for surgery he would have selected surgery in a NY minute. Here is the only stat I know, the surgeon that performed my operation, very well known and respected in this region, has performed approx 3000 of these operations over the last 10 years. One thing he did tell me early on, if my spots were G6, I would not have qualified for surgery. His diagnosis for my 1/G8 on the apex, was that we can kill the beast and get it out of your body before it decides to take on another path. We talked about radiation, and we could have gone that direction but once I heard what I had to do over the next several years as well as knowing that we may not beat it, the choice became obvious for both me and my wife. Especially knowing that surgery would no longer be an option. Most likely in the next 10 years PC patients will have yet another option to select, things are improving all the time. maybe in 20 years, RALP will be a thing of the past , who knows... best to you t

Posts.Title: Which treatment is most common?

Posts.Content: 7 more days, it felt like an eternity. But I'm ready, relaxed, stressed a bit, but relaxed. ready to move on. I know for me it's the right decision. This journey started well over a year ago when the very stable PSA rose from the hi 2's to the 3's then into the 4's then over 6 this past July. It was not a shock. Quite frankly I was expecting it. The Urologist who I have been seeing for a decade was never shy about using the C word over the last decade. July came , the biopsy was scheduled 5 weeks later, good grief the wait was near impossible . Then post biopsy, the call came , 2 positive spots out of 12. Certainly didn't want to hear this but it was not a shock. The conversations with the Urologist over the last couple of years prepared me for the worst case scenario. He did his job. And very well. Post Biopsy, scheduled appointment with the Surgeon, ( same office ) very detailed, very experienced, very positive , but yet held nothing back. To me this is critical , the flow of information and conversation with regard to whats ahead. No stone unturned. The doc went thru the entire procedure even showed us ( wife and I ) the surgical path, what he is going to do, where he is cutting, where he is not. Also plugged my numbers into the Sloan Kettering data base and showed us where we stand POST surgery. He answered questions I didn't even know to ask. Even those I didn't ask but wanted answers to. Life expectancy greater than 15 years better than 99% ( from this ) Cancer return possible after 10 years under 40 % from this , he believes it will be a lower % because the data base doesn't ask for the surgical path, it's just numbers. 10% incontinence possible 50% impotency possible One thing he made clear, his goal is NO CANCER, he does not spare muscle at the risk of any cancer remaining. He has done over 3000 RALP's and over 1000 non RALP. that in itself is amazing, the amount of men that go thru this. He did laugh and advised us that in 15 years I will bee seeing another Dr as he is retiring in 2 years. 15 years is a long time . I'll be right near 85, he will be 88. He did a Cystoscope during that pre-op visit, , it's terrible, 2 min of pure " I hate this". If someone says they are not that bad, they are indeed altering the truth Then the 6 week wait until surgery. just before I left the office he says..oh yeh, no more bread, pasta, potatoes, rice etc...until surgery. Drop 10 pounds please. And walk a mile a day. I'm about 15 or 20 pounds over where I should really be. So for 6 weeks, while waiting , no more of the good food I love, and yes, it looks like I dropped the 10 pounds or very close. I have been in constant communication with 2 or 3 friends who have been thru the same thing, I also stopped all Google searches as well. There is no point anymore. Other than a few visits to this forum now and then, I stay away. The folks on this forum are very positive and informative. people tell me I am very positive, I guess I am but treatment , surgery or chemo, is not a choice, it's mandatory. You can't dwell on it. We made the decision best for us, the Doc agrees and now the 6 weeks is just about here. I have 3 PRE Surgery appts today, Kegel exercises at the Hospital, then the final pre-surgery with the surgeons office, then back to the Hospital PRE OP for " how ya gonna pay for all this" . Long day, but the end is near. The only thing I want to know about now is the post surgery report. Thats where my mind is now, I'm beyond the surgery. 7 days to go.... I am still very nervous and have high anxiety. When I wake up after it's done, life will be somewhat different but my wife and I both agree that we will finally be on the other side of all of this.

AgeInfo.Phrase: near 85  he will be 88 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Which treatment is most common?

Posts.Content: Like many, I started kegels before surgery, maybe 1 week. 3 or 4 times a day. I visited the kegel rehab gal only once before surgery. She ran a butt muscle test on me, like an EKG but on my butt. I had to hold the muscles firm for 10 seconds maybe 5 times in a row and she graphed it. I didn't even know there was a such thing. regardless, she said my butt muscles were reporting the proper strength which was measured as a 4 or 5 on the graph scale. She told me the reason for this test was that the surgeon wanted to know how my muscles worked BEFORE the surgery as a ref. Well, they work. I was told I would not be back to see her unless I had total incontinence for a couple of months post surgery. She told me to do kegels several times a day which I do. Also of note, I weighed 187 when all this started, my target weight is probably 170, the Dr asked me to drop 10 pounds and walk at least 1 mile a day, he said I would thank him during post surgery recovery. I went with basically no carbs for 6 weeks and walked the 1 mile a day. At surgery I weighed in at 175 . Post surgery, yes, I am thanking him. My gut is much smaller and the incisions are really healing well. Getting up and down , sitting to standing, is obviously 13 pounds for the better. Standing from sitting or lying down is the #1 incontinence issue. Currently, I am 17 days post surgery, I have not soaked any pads, any depends or the bed . There is leakage, not a ton, mostly when standing up from sitting or lying down. I find I can hold it until I get to the bathroom, probably not a lot farther but I can hold it. I can also stop the stream if I try. So things are working . I have regular BM's every morning now as I did before the surgery. It took a few days after coming home from the Hosp for those to start and when they did, they became more regular each day. I find that I have the urge to pee , or at least it feels like it, to go to the bathroom every couple of hours. It seems that for first couple of weeks post surgery this is fairly common , as the bladder is also trying to recover. I don't fight it. If I feel like I gotta go, I'm going. I also try to hold it at this time, and find I can, at least briefly. One thing I know, I am not 100% incontinent, probably not even 50% . I think I am somewhere in the 25% window. I can hold it and I am not really wetting anything but I don't really know how long I can hold it yet. In one more week I am changing from Depends to regular underwear with a pad, You can't go to a urinal with the Depends, there is not 'SLOT' in the front. When I make the change I feel like I will be able to petty much go anywhere , no restrictions. I may use the Depends at night for another period of time just in case. Do know that when standing from sitting or when coughing or sneezing, there will be leakage, maybe a very large drop. How is that measured in incontinence % ? I don't know. But it is not a full emptying of the bladder. In comparison, whenever my wife laughs big time, coughs or sneezes, she gives up a drop, always has. I am doing kegels several times a day although If I exert too much holding pressure, 1 or 2 of my incisions tells me to lighten up ! Reflecting back, dropping that 13 pounds pre surgery , at the time I didn't understand the significance, now I do. Hope all this helps best to you t

Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: Like many, I started kegels before surgery, maybe 1 week. 3 or 4 times a day. I visited the kegel rehab gal only once before surgery. She ran a butt muscle test on me, like an EKG but on my butt. I had to hold the muscles firm for 10 seconds maybe 5 times in a row and she graphed it. I didn't even know there was a such thing. regardless, she said my butt muscles were reporting the proper strength which was measured as a 4 or 5 on the graph scale. She told me the reason for this test was that the surgeon wanted to know how my muscles worked BEFORE the surgery as a ref. Well, they work. I was told I would not be back to see her unless I had total incontinence for a couple of months post surgery. She told me to do kegels several times a day which I do. Also of note, I weighed 187 when all this started, my target weight is probably 170, the Dr asked me to drop 10 pounds and walk at least 1 mile a day, he said I would thank him during post surgery recovery. I went with basically no carbs for 6 weeks and walked the 1 mile a day. At surgery I weighed in at 175 . Post surgery, yes, I am thanking him. My gut is much smaller and the incisions are really healing well. Getting up and down , sitting to standing, is obviously 13 pounds for the better. Standing from sitting or lying down is the #1 incontinence issue. Currently, I am 17 days post surgery, I have not soaked any pads, any depends or the bed . There is leakage, not a ton, mostly when standing up from sitting or lying down. I find I can hold it until I get to the bathroom, probably not a lot farther but I can hold it. I can also stop the stream if I try. So things are working . I have regular BM's every morning now as I did before the surgery. It took a few days after coming home from the Hosp for those to start and when they did, they became more regular each day. I find that I have the urge to pee , or at least it feels like it, to go to the bathroom every couple of hours. It seems that for first couple of weeks post surgery this is fairly common , as the bladder is also trying to recover. I don't fight it. If I feel like I gotta go, I'm going. I also try to hold it at this time, and find I can, at least briefly. One thing I know, I am not 100% incontinent, probably not even 50% . I think I am somewhere in the 25% window. I can hold it and I am not really wetting anything but I don't really know how long I can hold it yet. In one more week I am changing from Depends to regular underwear with a pad, You can't go to a urinal with the Depends, there is not 'SLOT' in the front. When I make the change I feel like I will be able to petty much go anywhere , no restrictions. I may use the Depends at night for another period of time just in case. Do know that when standing from sitting or when coughing or sneezing, there will be leakage, maybe a very large drop. How is that measured in incontinence % ? I don't know. But it is not a full emptying of the bladder. In comparison, whenever my wife laughs big time, coughs or sneezes, she gives up a drop, always has. I am doing kegels several times a day although If I exert too much holding pressure, 1 or 2 of my incisions tells me to lighten up ! Reflecting back, dropping that 13 pounds pre surgery , at the time I didn't understand the significance, now I do. Hope all this helps best to you t

Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: welcome and thanks for posting. Sorry to learn of this situation for your your dad. There is no harm in seeking guidance from the cardiologist and following his orders. This is indeed a major surgery. I am certainly no Dr but will offer an opinion regarding the other concerns. Gleason 7 is a serious concern and needs to be treated soon, but, . if your Urologist said waiting another 6 months is acceptable, thats his call and his alone. Surgery is certainly a viable option and I can say from my own experience , while others here are very similar, they put you out, you wake up 5 or 6 hours later with a Catheter and spend one or two nights in the Hospital. I had minimal pains and required no medications. We are not allowed to do anything really physical for 6 weeks so activity is really at a low. Basically we are sitting around , watching TV and taking short walks and taking naps. Doing very little. The healing time was very painless and easy. I think our hearts are getting a good long rest ! There is no oral medication that I am aware of that we can take during the waiting period PRE Surgery, to fight the cancer cells. The good news is Prostate Cancer is a very slow growing entity, I have a few friends who have taken easily 6 months to make a decision from the time of diagnosis to treatment so that "time" window appears to be not an issue. We all also know others who have had the C cells for years undetected even though they had multiple biopsy's. One friend went just shy of two years before it was even discovered, even though his PSA tests were coming back very high time and time again. I think he had 3 biopsy's and then two MRI's before discovering the bad cells. Post Surgery he is doing just fine, cancer free. Wishing you the best, keep us updated. t

Posts.Content: Was this his first PSA test ever ? 60 is indeed a rather high number at 51 years old and suggests a follow up and some sort of exam sooner rather than later . While this can be viewed as very bad news, look at the positive, it has been revealed and warrants a test of some sort , revealing cancer or not. Better to learn it NOW than to not learn it at all. Most of us , if not all of us responding ,have been where you are. Try to relax, get the follow up tests done and let us know how things are going ! You are among friends here. best to you and your husband. t

Posts.Title: PSA of 60

Posts.Content: Surgery scheduled for Nov 21. Had the cystoscope yesterday, the surgeon does this with every patient pre-surgery. It's not that it is a pain thing but rather really uncomfortable. More in the 'good grief" category. Thank god it only lasts 1 min or 2. It's very quick. My bladder and all area's were clear. no surprises. The surgeon has performed 3400 RARP procedures and over 1000 pre- RARP procedures, he is very complete, very detailed, very positive. He also had my wife and I watch a video of the RARP so we knew what to expect and how it is performed. It's pretty amazing. All this being said, it's never a good situation to have these bad cells in us but at least knowing you are in the right place and in the right hands takes the edge off, somewhat. The Doc feels he is probably going to downgrade my Gleason 8 to a 7 based on the lab results and other criteria. He spent a great deal of time talking about POST surgery, what to expect , lab results, then on to life style . He has me starting on "sildenafil" ( 20mg) right now.( Viagra) Pre surgery , he wants to insure that I don't have any side effects . This script is not for recreation but rather 'blood flow" for the muscle bundles. He recommends I take it every day for 1 year. I can deal with it, it's $ 1/ pill. He has already advised me on the surgical path to remove the prostate, one muscle bundle will be near 100 % spared but the opposite side he is taking 50% of the bundle. One of my bad cells is near the edge and he wants it gone so he is stepping over the line as the preemptive measure. He told us that the rate of returning bad cells post surgery is under 5% with all of his patients, no return for everyone is the ultimate goal. This is why he is not going to try to spare the 2nd muscle bundle 100%. My wife and I know what to expect from this going forward. No secrets. No cancer is the goal. He ran my numbers thru the Sloan Kettering website calculator and the long term numbers are in my favor over the long haul. Survival rate ( from this) past 15 years better than 99%. Then there are several other factor rates in the 10 year period such as likely hood of cells popping up in the same area, whereas those are in the under 40 % category, but even he commented that there are things that are not factored in, such as the surgical path. he feels that the 10 year possible return factor will be much lower in my situation. Each case is different. In 15 years I will be near 85, in 10 near 80 , I feel I can be comfortable with these stats. All of the pre-surgery procedures are completed, now it's on to Nov 21, and then what follows. The most important thing we are looking for is a negative lab report following surgery, he feels I am in the under 5% category for a positive ( bad) report. He reminded us that there is no such thing as a 100% guarantee of a negative report and that an under 5% chance of seeing bad cells on the post surgery report is quite good. Thats all for now... wishing you all the best, stay the course. tony

Posts.Title: First visit with Surgeon PRE-Surgery

Posts.Content: Justin, welcome and thx for your post. Do realize that many of us here have been thru a similar circumstance. You are not alone and this is not uncommon. My take would be , (I'm not a Dr), is that the the Sloan Kettering 3+4=7 is more likely to be the case . What you didn't mention is the % of the grade 7 which may imply low risk. Regardless, I agree with Highlander above, with your very young age and high PSA numbers , the red flag is waving, and has been for a pretty long time. The good news is , whatever grade you have , 6 or 7, you now know it, that beats not knowing every day of the week. I suggest getting to an oncologist for treatment discussions without anymore delay. Prostate cancer is slow moving but it's still moving. Also keep in mind that when we go for biopsy's , the dreaded news is that sometimes it can take several biopsy's to report back the findings . If the sample size is small and the % is small, it can be easily undetected. The core sample could have missed it. A very close friend had 4 biopsy's over a two year period with a very HI PSA, they all came back negative. Fortunately the Uro wasn't convinced and ordered some sort of special MRI which finally discovered positive cells in a very small confined area of the prostate which a biopsy would never have found. A year now, post surgery he is doing fine and is cancer free. As crazy as this seems, learning that we have prostate cancer is a really bad day, no doubt, but look at it as a positive. Having it and not knowing it is FAR worse and can even be life threatening. You are on the right road , we all hate to hear it but it is what it is, we can't change it, but we can treat it with incredible success. When I was diagnosed last Sept, it was like a dark cloud was glued to my head. Once we (wife and I) discussed and decided on treatment with the oncologist, our minds went right past the surgery to the post op lab report and surgery was still 6 weeks away. I was able to relax and just go about life PRE Surgery. The worst was over, I knew the bad news and we decided on a treatment. That was now behind us. Going forward with a positive treatment plan with your oncologist , whatever plan that may be, is the right thing to do, and now. Wishing you the best, stay the course, stay positive. t

Prostate cancer is slow moving but it's still moving. Also keep in mind that when we go for biopsy's , the dreaded news is that sometimes it can take several biopsy's to report back the findings . If the sample size is small and the % is small, it can be easily undetected. The core sample could have missed it. A very close friend had 4 biopsy's over a two year period with a very HI PSA, they all came back negative. Fortunately the Uro wasn't convinced and ordered some sort of special MRI which finally discovered positive cells in a very small confined area of the prostate which a biopsy would never have found. A year now, post surgery he is doing fine and is cancer free. As crazy as this seems, learning that we have prostate cancer is a really bad day, no doubt, but look at it as a positive. Having it and not knowing it is FAR worse and can even be life threatening. You are on the right road , we all hate to hear it but it is what it is, we can't change it, but we can treat it with incredible success. When I was diagnosed last Sept, it was like a dark cloud was glued to my head. Once we (wife and I) discussed and decided on treatment with the oncologist, our minds went right past the surgery to the post op lab report and surgery was still 6 weeks away. I was able to relax and just go about life PRE Surgery. The worst was over, I knew the bad news and we decided on a treatment. That was now behind us. Going forward with a positive treatment plan with your oncologist , whatever plan that may be, is the right thing to do, and now. Wishing you the best, stay the course, stay positive. t

Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Rick, not to worry. I am now just over 5 months post surgery. Typically a Doc may recommend taking 20 MG/ Day of Sildenafil, which I have been taking since early Nov last year. I am still taking it. ED is a very common "AFTER Surgery" thing. For SEX, typically 100 MG is the recommended dosage, so 4 or 5 pills is appropriate. Now, on the other side is "other methods" . I just recently began injection therapy as the 100 MG dosage had minimal effect, even with sensations. Some say it is too early to begin therapy but others say if it feels right, get it started. We are all different and we all react differently. The point is to wake it up. I am having reasonable success with the injection therapy, both the Pharmacist and Doc want to know all the details . So far ( a few trial injections) I have no bad issues or side effects related to the trimix injections. 3 Months may be a bit premature but really your Doc is the one who gets to decide that based on your healing progress. Wishing you the best for a fast recovery, don't rush it though. We feel good on the outside but inside our body is still angry at us for the surgery ! t

Posts.Title: Erectile dysfunction after da vinci surgery

Posts.Content: Lots of variations it seems. Post Surgery, My Dr. told me to drop 10 pounds before surgery. I was only about 20 over. I had 6 weeks to do it. I basically cut out all extra carbs, no pasta, no rice, no potatoes, no bread , no snacks. I thought it would be difficult, it was not at all. I ate cold cuts, cheese, my wife cooked her typical meals, chicken, beef, pork without the carb sides . We sub'd with veggies which I am not a big fan of. I still had Ice Cream, drank my coffee and lots of water, got rid of Gatorade and soda. I ate more Banana's than a monkey and cans of Tuna in water, which surprisingly I always liked. I was not hungry. I didn't really miss the big carb dishes. The day before surgery, no solid food and only back coffee or water up to midnight. I drank that Magnesium Citrate stuff the day before. The day of surgery, nothing , no food no drink. I weighed in down 10 pounds at surgery. i started at 187. I was 177 at surgery. Post Surgery. Liquid diet until passing gas and first BM. From there they said eat away. No restrictions. My wife and I both changed our eating habits over that 6 week pre period, I dropped 10, I think she dropped 8 or so, she eats less than me. we have no plans to go full hog back to what we were doing so post surgery we indeed changed our eating habits. When I weighed in at the catheter removal last week I was down another 3 pounds, not surprised, I basically didn't eat any food of substance for 2 days before and 2 days following surgery. Even at that, once home my appetite was very small. I like that I dropped 13 pounds and would like to maintain most if the weight loss, which was mostly from no carbs . So with moderation I think all will be well. Post surgery, my feeling is it is best to eat lite, stay away from heavy foods , starches, spices, sauces etc,until the body has regained normalcy, this can probably take a few weeks. Go easy, use stool softeners, don't over eat, the body will like us ! I also think avoiding any alcohol is probably best for several weeks post. best to you t

Posts.Content: another, yes thanks. I am in no rush and it's easy to see that rushing is not going to help. I feel good, I want to do things, but I also know that just two weeks ago I had major surgery and I have the gut to prove it . Living life in slow motion for another month or two is really the plan. Yesterday, it was really nice out,hi 60's. I slowly washed the car with the hose and a long handle brush, I didn't do a very good job though . I don't even care !

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: all, thx so much for the replies. I am now 15 days post surgery and 5 days post catheter removal. Like stated above, it seems that I am getting the urges every 2 or 3 hours, so I go. I find I can HOLD it until I get to the toilet but I still have some leakage. I'm hoping that the urges get farther apart but I'm not waiting, if I feel pressure, I'm going. At night though, It's very uncomfortable, early night I have lots of pressure , swelling and throbbing , I can't find a comfortable position to sleep. I get up every couple of hours to pee, I'm not wetting the pads or anything like that though. Later in the night it appears to get better but I am still working in a 2 to 3 hour pee widow. Thats where I was PRE surgery with BPH. the difference now though is I know ( feel) I am emptying the bladder unlike before. There is a steam , not a dribble. I have to remind myself that I am still just 5 days post catheter removal and 15 days post surgery. I'm pretty certain that my body is not near where it should be. best to all t

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: I'm two weeks post surgery now and 4 days post catheter removal. Incisions healing very well, now black and blue though. My gut Looks like I was in a fight with a very short person who had good aim at my gut with his or her fists. regarding the catheter though, it was removed 4 days ago, it's still very strange. I "leak" , not when sitting or laying down, but when standing. I really can't tell if I have an urge to go or not, it's a strange sensation, it's more like pressure. yesterday and this morning, as I stood, I was able to squeeze and hold it for a short run to the toilet then release without leaking. I find I can stop the "stream" while it's in progress so I am assuming that this is good news on the way to " holding " it. I do get up to go to the toilet a few times at night just because I really can't say for certain what the urge feels like yet. I can't really tell whats going on yet. I feel some pressure thats about it. I am able to empty my bladder and for the most part the pads are either dry or just slightly wet, not soaked. I think I was expecting much worse, or maybe I don't really know what to expect. This is all new to me. Currently the biggest issue is when standing, I can hold it if I concentrate and try hard, but I still expect leakage. Before I shower, I empty my bladder , it seems I have a few minutes before it may decide to leak again so there is not much time to waste . It appears I am able to "hold" it for a brief time. If I cough or sneeze, I do have leakage, I can feel it happening. . I am on the last day of antibiotic meds and I do still have the spasm med ( oxybutynin 10 mg/) which I do take now and then, not everyday. Last night it was like I had big time pressure on my penis, but it passed after a few hours.I did take one of those spasm pills. I'll continue kegels several times a day but if I do them hard and firm, my incisions know it. best to all... t

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: wow sorry to hear this. I am 3 days post, I was told to NOT get the incisions wet, no soaking , no soap, just pat them with a wash cloth. They were adamant about this. Surprised they never advised you. I have 7 more days with the catheter , so we'll see. I also was recommended to just use the ONE Foley bag, which is what we will do, they gave me a smaller one but I have no plans to use it. The Dr told me that the bag and catheter was what he termed, my life line to the surgery , treat it all with the utmost care. best to you, hope you fell better real soon. t

Posts.Title: What to do? Two different Opinions

Posts.Content: Anthony, so very sorry to hear of your dads diagnosis, but if there is any good news, it is that he learned of it now. Learning of it is far better than not knowing. The other good news is there are treatments which can either cure and/ or allow him to have a long productive life. Early detection and treatment is the key. It's very difficult to learn that we have cancer, the dreaded disease that we all hope and pray we can avoid in our lifetime. But on the flip side is knowing we have it and treating it is 100% better than having it and NOT knowing, which allows it to run whatever path it happens to take. I suspect the Dr has the full report and has just not shared it yet , or maybe he did and it was not understood. They do not keep this a secret. This is the entire point of the biopsy. A PSA of 8 is an indicator , lower than some, higher that others. At his age of 62 it is generally accepted as being too high. The 5 positive spots are the true indicator but you really need to know the specific details for each spot, as mentioned above. That is the determining factor. What are the Gleason scores and what are the percentages for each positive core. For ex ; Gleason 6 is understood to perhaps only require "active surveillance " , while Geason 7 and above will suggest some form of treatment. Gleason 10 being the worst case which requires treatment, be it surgery or radiation. Before you can go forward this has to be known. Any treatment, any path forward , will be based on the identified positive cores and cancer percentages of the individual cores , then your dad along with the oncologist can make the best decision on which treatment to proceed with. The other good news is this is a slow moving entity, many of us here went several months from diagnosis to treatment and we all had the same anxiety's, what should I do, whats best for me. Your dad is not alone here . He is in remarkable company. Obtain the full report and add it to your forum signature , you do that by going to settings, edit signature. In this manner, those who comment can see the report details and comment accordingly. Maybe this will help ease the anxiety, I have friends ( we all do ) who have had either surgery or treatments, well over 10 years ago. All are still around living a good life. It seems that men our age, 60+, wherever we go, we hear, "yeh I had that done a few years ago" . We don't want to hear this stuff about ourselves obviously, and when when we do the anxiety runs high. But do know that it is very common and the cure rates are extremely high. Again, early detection and treatments are the key here. It sounds like you are very early in the process. If you can find a Dr closer to home, that is also a benefit and will not pose any issue for any current Dr you may have. best to you and your dad. Stay the course, stay positive. t

Posts.Content: lismil, I believe what Highlander stated above is accurate. Generally post surgery we do not get a PSA for approx 12 weeks. 6 weeks seems very fast and even 10 weeks may be too soon. In my own circumstance, I had surgery Nov 21, 2017, my 1st PSA is not scheduled until March 1st 2018. At first I thought that was really late but the Dr assured me that 12 or 16 weeks is the same thing and allows the body to get back to a more "natural" state. I'm not a Dr, so I trust what he says, so far he has been near 100 % accurate with pre surgery, surgery and post surgery expectations. Certainly follow up with additional testing as you are now beyond that 12 week window. Best to you, keep us up to date. t

Posts.Title: 0.1 PSA after surgery ... is this good or bad?

Posts.Content: I'm two weeks post surgery now and 4 days post catheter removal. Incisions healing very well, now black and blue though. My gut Looks like I was in a fight with a very short person who had good aim at my gut with his or her fists. regarding the catheter though, it was removed 4 days ago, it's still very strange. I "leak" , not when sitting or laying down, but when standing. I really can't tell if I have an urge to go or not, it's a strange sensation, it's more like pressure. yesterday and this morning, as I stood, I was able to squeeze and hold it for a short run to the toilet then release without leaking. I find I can stop the "stream" while it's in progress so I am assuming that this is good news on the way to " holding " it. I do get up to go to the toilet a few times at night just because I really can't say for certain what the urge feels like yet. I can't really tell whats going on yet. I feel some pressure thats about it. I am able to empty my bladder and for the most part the pads are either dry or just slightly wet, not soaked. I think I was expecting much worse, or maybe I don't really know what to expect. This is all new to me. Currently the biggest issue is when standing, I can hold it if I concentrate and try hard, but I still expect leakage. Before I shower, I empty my bladder , it seems I have a few minutes before it may decide to leak again so there is not much time to waste . It appears I am able to "hold" it for a brief time. If I cough or sneeze, I do have leakage, I can feel it happening. . I am on the last day of antibiotic meds and I do still have the spasm med ( oxybutynin 10 mg/) which I do take now and then, not everyday. Last night it was like I had big time pressure on my penis, but it passed after a few hours.I did take one of those spasm pills. I'll continue kegels several times a day but if I do them hard and firm, my incisions know it. best to all... t

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: all, thx so much for the replies. I am now 15 days post surgery and 5 days post catheter removal. Like stated above, it seems that I am getting the urges every 2 or 3 hours, so I go. I find I can HOLD it until I get to the toilet but I still have some leakage. I'm hoping that the urges get farther apart but I'm not waiting, if I feel pressure, I'm going. At night though, It's very uncomfortable, early night I have lots of pressure , swelling and throbbing , I can't find a comfortable position to sleep. I get up every couple of hours to pee, I'm not wetting the pads or anything like that though. Later in the night it appears to get better but I am still working in a 2 to 3 hour pee widow. Thats where I was PRE surgery with BPH. the difference now though is I know ( feel) I am emptying the bladder unlike before. There is a steam , not a dribble. I have to remind myself that I am still just 5 days post catheter removal and 15 days post surgery. I'm pretty certain that my body is not near where it should be. best to all t

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: lexpar. wishing you the best, do remember though that the entire purpose of the surgery is to rid you of the nasty entity. Many of us have been through it, probably all had the exact same emotions. Me included. I personally stayed really busy right up to the day before, knowing I had a 6 week wait before resuming physical activity. I did things around the yard, house etc well in advance. Once we, wife and I, made the decision for surgery our minds both raced way past the surgery to the pathology report following surgery, that became our focus . I hate to say that the surgery was a piece of cake , but it was a like piece of cake . No pains, no meds, couple of nights stay in the Hosp where they treated me like a king, then home for a 10 day relationship with Mr Catheter. Once the Catheter was removed the healing began and life was returning to somewhat normal rather rapidly. For sure it can be a battle of nerves but you will be on the other side soon. Wishing you the best t

Posts.Title: nervously waiting for surgery

Posts.Content: Mandy, I'm not a Dr but to me this may be typical and normal. There are many reasons for a slight PSA rise , Cancer is only one. At age 57, PSA 2.6 does not appear to be out of control or a sharp increase. As we get older our numbers rise, it's just what they do. He does however need to keep being tested yearly, this is how we , as we get older, stay informed. This is not a fight he wants to lose. Don't mean to embarrass you, but SEX before the PSA test can reveal a higher number. Many of us have experienced very similar PSA increases , of which they are just signs or a flag to have another test done . What the Docs are looking for are sharp INCREASES over a 1 year or so period, sometimes even less. By comparison, I am now 69, 10 years ago my numbers were hovering around 2, then gradually increased into the high 2's, then into the 3's . Over the last 24 months my numbers went from the 3's into the 4's then into the 6's. Thats a FLAG for a biopsy. You are very smart in asking these questions and then insisting on the yearly tests. If the numbers begin to rise you can even revert to 6 month testing. it is said that once we get into our late 60's going into our 70's, a PSA over 4 is not uncommon. But exceeding 4's can be a flag to an issue. My take on this is that every man over 55 should know what his PSA number is. Last year, this year , going into next year. It's a blood test, not an operation. It's tracking a trend. Don't take it for granted because all of a sudden it can be 15 or 20, or higher. Prostate Cancer is one that is treatable but you gotta know you have it to treat it. If we do not take action, Prostate Cancer can turn into something much worse which will require different treatments. Early detection is mandatory. best to you and your husband. t

Posts.Title: Worried Over PSA Levels

Posts.Content: Probably nothing to be alarmed with at this point. Do you have any symptoms or issues ? Anything changed in the last year or two ? Silly question, did you have sex shortly before the last PSA ? ( actually not so silly) You do not have to wait 1 year, get the PSA every 6 months if it gives you peace of mind. I did. But I'm also 69... Better to track it and KNOW what it is than putting it on the back burner. If we have no symptoms it's really the only flag we have for other possibilities. One thing though, don't miss a year. A very close friend ( older) had a rising PSA , he skipped one year, he either forgot or whatever, his PSA rose by a factor greater than 5X in just that 12 month period. Yes he had PCA. stay the course and be diligent. best to you t

Posts.Title: first biopsy

Posts.Content: While I read the document above , and I am not arguing with it, but it appears to imply that there are many men with REGRET over choosing RALP for localized treatment. I'm not sure I buy that. There are way too many factors as to why one man would choose a specific treatment over another man. I would agree however that EMOTIONS is huge. When we hear the words, " YOU HAVE CANCER" , we check out of the universe we are living in and begin a new life in an alternative universe, one where we are seeking the answers to "how do I get this stuff out of me" and "How long do I have" ? I suspect that once we hear a reasonable answer to question # 1, we make a decision . We now also have the ability to learn what other men have experienced, with similar but not exact circumstances. Regarding question #2, a seasoned Dr will answer it before we even ask it. It appears that most use the Sloan Kettering 15 year window of survival percentages. 15 years is a long time. My Mother had colon cancer, she passed 12 or 13 years later from heart disease. My father passed from a heart attack at 75, I'm 69, if I meet or exceed the 15 year window I will have lived 9 years longer than my father and he didn't even have cancer. I certainly am one for analyzing and reading stats , but somehow I think thats just what they are. An avenue for someone who is flat out scarred to find some emotional relief. Do these stats mean I am going to survive ? Am I going to live another 15 years or longer ? Good question. The stats do place us in a survival window but even at that, it's a percentage. The initial topic is posed as "localized" , when I was diagnosed it was expected and understood to be localized, they used 95% as the %, the Doc could never use 100% as the Prostate was inside of me, he couldn't look at it. All he could do was go by the MRI scans etc... I would be a bad stat to the above as I have no regrets. Question # 1 was still of primary importance, and as the various treatments were explained to me, I selected surgery ,as it was the best opportunity to get the dang cancer out of me, at this specific time, EARLY Detection. Had I waited another 6 months or a year, who can say. I can tell ya this, had I waited another year and then learned it was no longer localized, then I would have had regret. I indeed had that option. I had some time, but with a G8, I didn't have extended time. I realize that many men decide on other treatments which is excellent, thank god we have options, but we are each emotionally different , At that moment when we hear " you have cancer" , everything else just doesn't seem so important anymore. As stated earlier, many men , if it's possible, just want the cancer gone from our body . If the best opportunity to get the cancer out of our body is surgery, and it is indeed reported as localized with the post op path report, I don't see REGRET as even being part of the equation. I have no regrets , regardless of what the future offers. I can only speak for me though. t

Posts.Title: RALP vs RT: a study of treatment decision-making in men with localised PCa

Posts.Content: iicec, thanks for posting and sharing. Indeed thats a lot of positive spots. Even at G6. For my worries the %'s are very high which is an indicator of future concerns. At your young age, it is really best to go over the treatments that best fit you and your family's concerns with your urologist/oncologist . We can each share what was good for us but at the end of the day, although we may have similar circumstances, we are each very different and will respond to treatments differently. I have posted my post surgery experiences threads ( 7 days now ) ( tpjames ) for others to review and maybe gain some information. My recovery is going well and progress is tracking as expected and similar to others. I have learned tons from others before me and it has really helped me personally pre surgery as well as post surgery. Posts.Title: Not sure what treatment any help?

Posts.Content: While I read the document above , and I am not arguing with it, but it appears to imply that there are many men with REGRET over choosing RALP for localized treatment. I'm not sure I buy that. There are way too many factors as to why one man would choose a specific treatment over another man. I would agree however that EMOTIONS is huge. When we hear the words, " YOU HAVE CANCER" , we check out of the universe we are living in and begin a new life in an alternative universe, one where we are seeking the answers to "how do I get this stuff out of me" and "How long do I have" ? I suspect that once we hear a reasonable answer to question # 1, we make a decision . We now also have the ability to learn what other men have experienced, with similar but not exact circumstances. Regarding question #2, a seasoned Dr will answer it before we even ask it. It appears that most use the Sloan Kettering 15 year window of survival percentages. 15 years is a long time. My Mother had colon cancer, she passed 12 or 13 years later from heart disease. My father passed from a heart attack at 75, I'm 69, if I meet or exceed the 15 year window I will have lived 9 years longer than my father and he didn't even have cancer. I certainly am one for analyzing and reading stats , but somehow I think thats just what they are. An avenue for someone who is flat out scarred to find some emotional relief. Do these stats mean I am going to survive ? Am I going to live another 15 years or longer ? Good question. The stats do place us in a survival window but even at that, it's a percentage. The initial topic is posed as "localized" , when I was diagnosed it was expected and understood to be localized, they used 95% as the %, the Doc could never use 100% as the Prostate was inside of me, he couldn't look at it. All he could do was go by the MRI scans etc... I would be a bad stat to the above as I have no regrets. Question # 1 was still of primary importance, and as the various treatments were explained to me, I selected surgery ,as it was the best opportunity to get the dang cancer out of me, at this specific time, EARLY Detection. Had I waited another 6 months or a year, who can say. I can tell ya this, had I waited another year and then learned it was no longer localized, then I would have had regret. I indeed had that option. I had some time, but with a G8, I didn't have extended time. I realize that many men decide on other treatments which is excellent, thank god we have options, but we are each emotionally different , At that moment when we hear " you have cancer" , everything else just doesn't seem so important anymore. As stated earlier, many men , if it's possible, just want the cancer gone from our body . If the best opportunity to get the cancer out of our body is surgery, and it is indeed reported as localized with the post op path report, I don't see REGRET as even being part of the equation. I have no regrets , regardless of what the future offers. I can only speak for me though. t

Posts.Title: RALP vs RT: a study of treatment decision-making in men with localised PCa

Posts.Content: at 69, my PSA has risen from the mid 2's to recently 6.5 over the last 18 months. While the Doc was concerned about the 6.5 he was more concerned with what I think he referred to as the free PSA level which which typically was in the high teens and now was around 7 or 8. So Biopsy ordered and done, . Urologist, not GP. Been going to the Urologist for 10 years now. This is their skill set . He said my numbers on the big scale shows 25% no chance of C, 50% a possibility of C and 25% a probability of C. But he reminded me that it's numbers . The biopsy itself was not near the worst case procedure I thought it would be, the initial WAND or whatever we wanna call it, to me, was more uncomfortable that then actual 12 snips. I didn't find it to be painful but rather uncomfortable. The whole procedure took at best 10 or 12 minutes. Certainly we need to be on antibiotics for a day before , the day of and the day after. They also give an antibiotic injection just before the procedure. I had been given some relaxers, probably a Valium of sorts but decided to not take them, I have a pretty high threshold. The Doc told me he would call in a few days with the results and we would take it from there. Am I worried ? Sure, but not to the point of going crazy, gotta deal with it. If the snips are positive I have already decided to yank the prostate. If they are not, well, we'll just carry on . After conversations with several friends my age, who had the Prostate removed, they are enjoying life , sure with a few modifications of lifestyle, but otherwise carrying on. I also know a few who did NOT remove the Prostate and went with treatments. They are NOT doing well, it seems they are constantly dealing with the same issue, over and over again along with continued treatments. I'll report back in a few days. t

Posts.Title: first biopsy

Posts.Content: thank you all for the comments. Obviously concerned . I have been with McKay Urology in the Charlotte NC area for 8 or so years. Very well known and respected. The last 3 years I have been on a 6 month PSA, my choice. Only the last 3 periods did the rise get sharp and the last one had a very low Free PSA # as well. Not knowing all the lab results details at this time, I do have a scheduled appt. for Monday morning ( 4 days from now) which will hopefully reveal what should be done going forward. I will post all of the details of the lab results when I get them, they are not yet posted on my account on-line profile. If there is any good news ,( not actually good) it is that the first biopsy revealed 2 positive cores rather than having to repeat the biopsy several times which seems that at the end of the day they end up positive at some point. I am thinking this gets the whole process moving forward sooner rather than later. I am definitely a get it done now kind of person , waiting has never been a strong point for me. If I had to repeat the biopsy several times over a year or more I would have been stressed just from that alone. At least now I know whats going on. I am not shocked, disappointed yes, shocked, no. Thank you all, I wish none of us had to be on this board. Staying the course tony

Posts.Content: iicec, thanks for posting and sharing. Indeed thats a lot of positive spots. Even at G6. For my worries the %'s are very high which is an indicator of future concerns. At your young age, it is really best to go over the treatments that best fit you and your family's concerns with your urologist/oncologist . We can each share what was good for us but at the end of the day, although we may have similar circumstances, we are each very different and will respond to treatments differently. I have posted my post surgery experiences threads ( 7 days now ) ( tpjames ) for others to review and maybe gain some information. My recovery is going well and progress is tracking as expected and similar to others. I have learned tons from others before me and it has really helped me personally pre surgery as well as post surgery. Under your forum "settings" , edit your signature to include your stats, as this is helpful for others to offer insight as well. stay positive , as awful as it seems , the good news is you know what you have to deal with and that beats not knowing any day of the week. best to you t

Posts.Title: Not sure what treatment any help?

Posts.Content: THX All... mikesimm, I hear ya. I can go 3 maybe 3 1/2 hours at night which is two hours better than before surgery with BPH. During the day, all bets are off, it could be an hour , 2 hours , maybe 3, depends on activity. am I standing, walking, sitting...How much coffee did I drink, all that. I asked the Doc about this and he didn't seem concerned he was more concerned about being dry and being able to stay dry. Can I hold it " ? If I feel the urge, I' m going next opportunity. I don't care if it's 45 min, but I can hold it if I need to. IF I understood the conversation correctly, my bladder after many years of BPH may not bounce back so maybe 3, 3 1/2 hours, maybe I can get to 4, will be the new reference , of which I am fine with. I am cutting back on drinks that are diuretics, such as coffee and Ice Tea. Not cutting them out, cutting them back. Regardless though, I have improved over the last few weeks to the point where I really don't need a pad other than a false sense of dependence. Last week I just stopped using them. Yeah a small spot now and then but nothing overwhelming. Wishing you the best. t

Posts.Title: 3 months Post Surgery Club Zero Member

Posts.Content: 1st PSA since surgery Nov 21, reported < 0.1 which was stated as undetectable . Will be tested every 3 months for 2 years, then every 6 months for 2 years. Then, if all is well, once a year. I was told that anything reported .2 or above may require attention. We talked about many things, incontinence being one. I have never had an issue of WET at night and the stress incontinence during the day is less and less each week. Several weeks back I stopped using any pads at night and this week I have started with NO pads during the day. A very minimal drop now and then. I do understand that if I am doing any assertive work it would be good to use a thin pad. Regarding ED, still not woke up but sensations are there , something is going on, I can feel it waking up. I am now cleared to use 100 MG of Viagra (Sildenafil) , lets see what happens. Even though I was expecting to be a member of Club Zero, it is still a relief to hear the words and learn the results. Been a crazy last 6 months thats for sure. best to all t

Posts.Title: 3 months Post Surgery Club Zero Member

Posts.Content: Busby, sorry to hear of your discomfort. the first few months can easily be SORE even though some of us are less sore than others. I recall I had one incision that was a pain, somewhat, and it took easily 6 weeks for it to diminish. Wile I am not a Dr, how we move around during the day, how much activity, the kind of activity etc all matters. Sleeping positions etc...As long as you are reporting this to the Doc and he or she is not concerned right now, just take it slow. Your recover may just take longer than others. there are no hard and fast rules here. Just take it easy. G O S L O W best to you t

Posts.Title: Post RP - How long for discomfort to go away?

Posts.Content: ANWANK, welcome ! You are asking excellent questions . It does appear to me that Dr's have a flag raised due to family history and the young age of 48. I would much rather have too much concern rather than too little concern. As mentioned above ,the two negative DRE's are just an indication that there is not a growth on the outside of the prostate, the DRE is not the same as a biopsy or a PSA, it's in addition to. I had Prostate Cancer, all of my DRE's were negative and each time the Dr's said that my Prostate, although slightly enlarged , showed negative for any outside tumors. The cancer was INSIDE the Prostate. My take on the elevated PSA at age 48 is that whatever test the URO's recommend, do it and do it sooner rather than later. The best thing that you can learn is they all come back negative. If they come back positive, sure it's bad news but the good news is it is very early and successful treatments are available. Stay the course with the Dr's, it really appears they are on top of this. I believe everyone here fully understands the anxiety that comes with this, try to relax . let us know. t

Posts.Title: Time, and then, always, progression.

Posts.Content: Hi Owen, being in a very similar situation right now, I am going forward with surgery. I had two early detection positive cores out of 12, Gleason 3+3=6 ( 10%) and Gleason 4+4=8 (15%). it's the Gleason 8 that is the defining factor . Is surgery the only option ? No of course not. At age 69 my wife and I are in 100% agreement that the best solution for me, is indeed surgery. We can live with the outcome and lifestyle changes, whatever they may be. The decision for which treatment you select needs to fit your plans for life going forward. Can we be ok with cells still in our body or can we feel more relieved with them gone and deal with some other things ? It's not an easy decision. One thing is for certain, Gleason 7 is right on the cusp, Gleason 6 is below the cusp , a treatment decision is required. For me it was personally not a hard decision , surgery scheduled for Nov 21 . Learning and knowing what the effects and schedule of radiation treatments are from the your Doc vs the removal and it's effects are paramount. Which treatment better serves your life style ? The good news is both can be very successful going forward. Each of us are different and each treatment will effect each of us differently. I have a handful of very close friends who opted for surgery and all are doing just fine, two of them are over 10 years now and adjusted well. One friend who opted for radiation is still dealing with some on going issues, but he as well is over 10 years. Two friends had the treatments at age 55, they are both closer to my age now, over 10 years. The one thing we all must keep in mind is with radiation treatment we know we still have cells inside us that we are hopeful to eliminate over time, with the surgery we are hopeful that after surgery our bad cells are in the trash can. We pray for an excellent post surgery NEGATIVE lab report. Then we live with the post surgery circumstances. You have excellent options available, regardless if it is Radiation or Surgery. The option that best fits your life style going forward , what to expect, whats involved, will be the determining factor. wishing you the absolute best tony

Posts.Title: Options for early stage prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Jake, sorry to read about your C... Seeing you only live 1 hr away from JH, thats the easy and short answer for a 2nd opinion. The bad news and the good news is you have learned you have the C, so now all you have to do is select a treatment that best suits you lifestyle going forward. While it is certainly true that many select surgery, it is also true that a seasoned DOC is what you want. One with hundreds if not thousands of surgery's under his or her belt. Should you select surgery. One of the main items often not mentioned with regard to surgery is the % of patients that come out with "CONFINED TO THE PROSTATE" results, which means no more C breeding inside. That doesn't suggest that surgery is the better treatment but it may suggest that removing it from our body and not requiring further treatments or meds, is a welcomed relief, regardless of the AFTER effects. The emotions associated with "C" being gone cannot be overlooked. Learning that you have a single G7 has a great deal to do with the type of treatment you select, especially at your age. It suggests CONFINED which is also a primary reason why many URO's would recommend surgery. The ultimate goal is Cancer free. That is first and foremost. Dealing with after effects is not the same as dealing with a Cancer treatment. What I do feel all URO'S will agree with ,or at least should, is that your G7 will will indeed turn into a G8 or worse. Right now, a quality URO is looking at treating a single G7 with the best possible outcome . THAT IS THEIR CHARGE. Thats what is in front of them right now. Nothing else. It's not an easy decision but the good news is you have options. Go to JH, let them be the 2nd opinion. At age 55 you have an entire life out in front of you. The life you select going forward is no longer the same life you had just a few months back. Regardless of the treatment you select, you will adjust, alter and modify your daily habits. Thats not a bad thing. Surviving and treating Prostate Cancer is GOOD thing and never lose sight of that. Peeing into a Depends is nothing in the scheme of things if C is eliminated and removed from your body. I am an advocate of any treatment that fits a persons desires, I don't say select one over another, I do say select one and don't look back. Removing or eliminating Cancer is the goal, not the after effects of the treatments. We gotta get to first base before we can steal 2nd. Best to you on your journey, get over to JH as soon as possible is my take. Let us know ! t

Posts.Title: new member, first post, got the PC news yesterday

Posts.Content: I thought I would offer an update for those that are in the post surgery healing process. A reference so to speak. I am now 10 weeks post , I feel great, no physical issues what-so-ever. The incisions are totally healed it seems, they are small scars now. I got rid of Depends about 2 or 3 weeks ago and am back to Haynes briefs, but still use a pad. Although there really is not overwhelming activity on the pad, minimal. The leaking during the day is still there, minimal, but still there. Mostly when standing from a sitting position or from excessive activity. Compared to 3,4 , 5 weeks ago it's like night and day. Plus I refuse to give up my two cups of coffee each morning which I am sure is contributing. My night time is 100% dry and has been since the surgery. The amount of time I get up to go to the bathroom has increased from about every two hours to just about 4 hours. This is huge for me. I have not slept 4 hours straight for the last 7 or 8 years due to BPH. Maybe I can get to 5 hours.... I walk at least 1/2 mile each day doing kegels as a I walk. My diet is still lean on carbs although I cheat. I lost 13 pounds pre-surgery and would like to keep that weight off. I was 20 pounds overweight at 188 now I am in the 175 range. regarding ED, still not active but things are happening. I am on 20 MG sildenafil daily, I expect that to be raised to 50 soon. I have sensation. I can feel it waking up. I am still 4 weeks away from my first post op PSA. We are all expecting zero, thats the plan. My daily routines are back 100% but I am aware that I have a pad in the Haynes. I am not afraid to use the restrooms wherever I may be. The stream is excellent , unlike the last 7 or 8 years of inconsistent weak stream due to BPH . It's a relief. If I was arrogant I would say the surgery was worth this alone, but I'm trying not to be arrogant anymore. Life on the other side of cancer surgery is different than the life PRE Surgery. I take nothing for granted, The things that bothered me in life before have zero significance in the scheme of things. The things I took for granted now have 100% significance. To be told that we have cancer is a tuff deal, a hard pill to swallow. But with the proper Dr's , treatments and support , it becomes like a fresh start, a reset so to speak. I clearly am not afraid of tomorrow. If my proposed time here on earth is 15 more years then it will be filled with 15 years of positive days with appreciation for my family ,friends and surroundings. best to all, stay the course, stay positive. t

Posts.Title: 10 weeks post surgery

Posts.Content: MM, when my PSA started rising, gradually, I moved to 6 month testing from 12 month testing, this was 18 to 24 months ago. At this point , unless a DR recommends against it , I would move to 6 month testing. A biopsy at this point is probably not going to be recommended either , not enough trend information, especially with the drop in your PSA There are many reasons for a rising PSA, cancer is just one of them. At 56, you may experience a slight rise, so they say, but it's really the trend ( slope) that matters , not the number. I was in the 2's then the 3's then the 4's then up to the 6's. The trend was bad. No need to worry. Just stay the course , stay on top of it, stay informed. You are way ahead of the game, you are being tested and you know what your numbers are. best to you t
