Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I'd wait on the injections. I had adverse effects. Erection recovered on its own in 12 to 18 months. Cialis had an effect when sildenafil did not. While I have read many instances where this has occurred , after visiting with two PRE Injection therapists, it is not uncommon but not very common either. It can be corrected. There are a few factors to take into consideration, one being the actual injection and injection site, the other is the TRI MIX. I have been advised by both PRE visits that the TRI MIX blend itself can cause some issues and can easily be corrected. One mix is not the same for each person. One dose is not the same for each person, thats why it is a compound blend , it is specific to the person. The starting point of the blend may be the same but the final blend will vary. I don't start until next week after I see the PA. The Compound Pharmacist is also involved, they want to know how it all went down, was there pain, was there sensation ,was there no response, too much response , many questions. It's not just inject and go. Where the injection takes place is also critical, not difficult but must be in the right "zone". I was told that approx 20% of men have a reasonably good reaction with the initial mix at .2 Inj , but 80% need a higher Inj volume or re-mix to zero it in. There is indeed one element of the compound which can cause some pain and maybe a reaction, that ingredient goes down while one of the others goes up. The Pharmacist Consult told me the plan is to adjust the mix so the Inj volume can remain low. It's a balance thing , he works with the DOC , he is part of the team. He is not working the counter at Walgreens, he is specific. Every script they fill is based on each individual , consult is part of their charge. In our home, we know about these Compound Pharmacy folks and blends really well, my wife has been on hormone blends for a few years now. It took a few months for it all to work out but after that it was like taking an aspirin. While it is true that some men don't respond to injections it is also true that many do. There are way too many factors to state that it doesn't work or why it doesn't work. Health, physical cond, age etc... I asked the Doc about Sildenafil vs Cialis, actually two Docs, both said the same thing, they are basically one and the same, one has a higher dosage than the other. They both have the exact same purpose, blood flow. Again, it's back to each person is different , each of us respond differently to different meds. Health, physical cond, age etc... What may work for person A may have zero effect for person B. Regarding long term, I was told that near half the men who take injections, it's possible that over a year or so period, ED will cure on it's own. But no guarantees. It's worth the effort to try. I certainly have read the accounts where it was painful and didn't work, but I have also read the accounts that were just the opposite. Will it work for me ? Will I have reactions ? Can't say, but it's sure worth a try.

Posts.Title: ED.....Patience??....Feeling a tad useless down there

Posts.Content: yep bring your Mr Depends with you and maybe an extra pad or two. When the Nurse told me she was pulling the Catheter out , she said it will be on 3...I counted, 1,2 she had already pulled it out before I got to 3. No pain just a weird sensation for 2 or 3 seconds. I didn't drop much urine, a very small amount . Don't worry they got you covered, they are prepared and will give you what you need. I put on the Depends with an extra pad and went home, maybe a 45 min drive. I never had an issues with pee'ing, I always felt the urge and was able to get to the toilet in time. It was the leaking that was the most annoying. As stated above, don't judge control by days, judge it by weeks. I am now 6 months post and the leaking is pretty much totally gone. I do drop a spot now and then with physical activity but even that is getting less and less. Just give it all time, don't try to rush things. At home you need a pack or two of Depends and maybe the extra heavy pads. We bought too many and returned them. By 3 months I went to Haynes Briefs with a lite-duty pad. t

Posts.Content: I thought I would post this for those who may be lurking and may be considering surgery but are on the fence. My stat numbers are below, no need to address those again. Surgery end of Nov 2017, now at 4 months , one side nerve bundle spared, the other side cut wide. No pains, no meds, complete physical healing and return to regular activities at the 6 week window. Incontinence was never an issue at night but the slight leaking during the day was annoying . Standing , activities etc, not excessive, slight. Stopped using pads at around 10 weeks. TODAY, , leakage is even less, very minimal , hardly noticeable , I'm talking about during activities . A spot the size of a dime or a quarter. My wife drops more than I do ! regarding ED though, 100 MG Slidenafil didn't work for me. I'm on 20 mg /day regardless but the boost to 100 mg didn't bring me back. I have sensations and even some "minimal" partials but still have ED. April 10 I have an appointment with the Injections folks. My tri mix prescription is waiting at the Compound Pharmacy. We are expecting that this will return this part of my life back to functional. Other than the ED, which we are addressing, the post surgery recovery has been a very smooth ride, as expected. I'm turning 70 this year, I'm very active, I act like I'm 21 but my body reminds me that I am not. t

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I'd wait on the injections. I had adverse effects. Erection recovered on its own in 12 to 18 months. Cialis had an effect when sildenafil did not. While I have read many instances where this has occurred , after visiting with two PRE Injection therapists, it is not uncommon but not very common either. It can be corrected. There are a few factors to take into consideration, one being the actual injection and injection site, the other is the TRI MIX. I have been advised by both PRE visits that the TRI MIX blend itself can cause some issues and can easily be corrected. One mix is not the same for each person. One dose is not the same for each person, thats why it is a compound blend , it is specific to the person. The starting point of the blend may be the same but the final blend will vary. I don't start until next week after I see the PA. The Compound Pharmacist is also involved, they want to know how it all went down, was there pain, was there sensation ,was there no response, too much response , many questions. It's not just inject and go. Where the injection takes place is also critical, not difficult but must be in the right "zone". I was told that approx 20% of men have a reasonably good reaction with the initial mix at .2 Inj , but 80% need a higher Inj volume or re-mix to zero it in. There is indeed one element of the compound which can cause some pain and maybe a reaction, that ingredient goes down while one of the others goes up. The Pharmacist Consult told me the plan is to adjust the mix so the Inj volume can remain low. It's a balance thing , he works with the DOC , he is part of the team. He is not working the counter at Walgreens, he is specific. Every script they fill is based on each individual , consult is part of their charge. In our home, we know about these Compound Pharmacy folks and blends really well, my wife has been on hormone blends for a few years now. It took a few months for it all to work out but after that it was like taking an aspirin. While it is true that some men don't respond to injections it is also true that many do. There are way too many factors to state that it doesn't work or why it doesn't work. Health, physical cond, age etc... I asked the Doc about Sildenafil vs Cialis, actually two Docs, both said the same thing, they are basically one and the same, one has a higher dosage than the other. They both have the exact same purpose, blood flow. Again, it's back to each person is different , each of us respond differently to different meds. Health, physical cond, age etc... What may work for person A may have zero effect for person B. Regarding long term, I was told that near half the men who take injections, it's possible that over a year or so period, ED will cure on it's own. But no guarantees. It's worth the effort to try. I certainly have read the accounts where it was painful and didn't work, but I have also read the accounts that were just the opposite. Will it work for me ? Will I have reactions ? Can't say, but it's sure worth a try.

Posts.Title: ED.....Patience??....Feeling a tad useless down there

Posts.Content: Well I know none of you have heard from me personally before, but allow me to take this opportunity to introduce myself as bpjames (aka - the wife - lol). This forum has been a real inspiration and help to both my husband and I over the past 10 weeks and I know will continue to do so. I hope this update will be of similar assistance to you and your loved ones during your journey. We were blessed to have a great team who were very detailed before the operation. My husband was the third surgery for his surgeon for the day so, the actual surgery began at approx. 1:00 in the afternoon. The surgeon greeted me at 5:10 pm and told me that my husband tolerated the surgery very well and while the final pathology report (due out on Monday) should confirm his diagnosis he saw nothing that would suggest that the cancer spread outside of the prostate and feels good that it remained contained. He also downgraded one of his positive cancer spots from an 8 to a 7. My husband was moved from recovery to his room within 2 hours. Within an 1-1/2 hours they let me sit with him. Do take note not to be alarmed at the very short term swelling to the face that occurs immediately after surgery. That is due to your head being tilted back during surgery which causes fluids to settle in the head and face. This is normal and within a few hours goes away. There is also a small balloon type drain attached to the his side which drains the blood that has collected where the operated. The belly is also very swollen immediately after surgery (but again - nothing to be alarmed about) simply a heads up to your wife/family to be aware of. My husband was coming in and out of the sedation and by 11:00 Pm was very aware. It is now 7:00 am (next day) and I am heading back to the hospital to be with the greatest husband in the world (had to come home last night to let Homer the cat in the house). I would be lying to you to say that I am not dog tired - so loved ones due rest up before the surgery. I think it is the body finally relaxing after 10 long weeks of wait. Spoke with my husband this morning - yes he called me at 5:45 am and he sounds very alert and while his IV is still pushing a very mild pain med. He said he is not in any pain. The only complaint right after surgery he had and I think you can guess what it is was the catheter. It was not painful - just uncomfortable and making him feel like he had to go. Well, I'm off to the hospital. My thoughts and prayers are with each and every one of you about to take this journey. My deepest thanks again to all of you for your kindness, support and experiences you have shared on this site. P.S My husband sends his thanks and said he will keep you posted. With kind regards - The wife !

Posts.Title: Surgery is done tpjames wife reporting

Posts.Content: Well I know none of you have heard from me personally before, but allow me to take this opportunity to introduce myself as bpjames (aka - the wife - lol). This forum has been a real inspiration and help to both my husband and I over the past 10 weeks and I know will continue to do so. I hope this update will be of similar assistance to you and your loved ones during your journey. We were blessed to have a great team who were very detailed before the operation. My husband was the third surgery for his surgeon for the day so, the actual surgery began at approx. 1:00 in the afternoon. The surgeon greeted me at 5:10 pm and told me that my husband tolerated the surgery very well and while the final pathology report (due out on Monday) should confirm his diagnosis he saw nothing that would suggest that the cancer spread outside of the prostate and feels good that it remained contained. He also downgraded one of his positive cancer spots from an 8 to a 7. My husband was moved from recovery to his room within 2 hours. Within an 1-1/2 hours they let me sit with him. Do take note not to be alarmed at the very short term swelling to the face that occurs immediately after surgery. That is due to your head being tilted back during surgery which causes fluids to settle in the head and face. This is normal and within a few hours goes away. There is also a small balloon type drain attached to the his side which drains the blood that has collected where the operated. The belly is also very swollen immediately after surgery (but again - nothing to be alarmed about) simply a heads up to your wife/family to be aware of. My husband was coming in and out of the sedation and by 11:00 Pm was very aware. It is now 7:00 am (next day) and I am heading back to the hospital to be with the greatest husband in the world (had to come home last night to let Homer the cat in the house). I would be lying to you to say that I am not dog tired - so loved ones due rest up before the surgery. I think it is the body finally relaxing after 10 long weeks of wait. Spoke with my husband this morning - yes he called me at 5:45 am and he sounds very alert and while his IV is still pushing a very mild pain med. He said he is not in any pain. The only complaint right after surgery he had and I think you can guess what it is was the catheter. It was not painful - just uncomfortable and making him feel like he had to go. Well, I'm off to the hospital. My thoughts and prayers are with each and every one of you about to take this journey. My deepest thanks again to all of you for your kindness, support and experiences you have shared on this site. P.S My husband sends his thanks and said he will keep you posted. With kind regards - The wife !

Posts.Title: Surgery is done tpjames wife reporting

Posts.Content: rjb, glad to hear things went well. The catheter can cause all sorts of weird sensations. For me , immediately following surgery I had the urge to PEE big time , this lasted for a few hours, but after that evidently my bladder understood it had a visitor that was not leaving. I never felt any urges to PEE from that point on. I stayed on the large bag for my 10 days, I really had no need to use the small bag. I probably emptied the bag 3 or 4 times a day and maybe once at night. I don't think it ever got more than half full at night. Sounds like you are on a good road back to a normal life, don't push it, don't rush, let your recovery happen in it's OWN time. The question was raised above about the catheter , peeing and feeling. For me, there was no feeling of having to pee ever, it just drained into the bag, 24/7. Thats what they are supposed to do. I did have some bladder spasms now and then but nothing earth shattering. Stay the course, wishing you a great recovery t

Posts.Title: Live from Room 427

Posts.Content: Interesting read, here is my point of view. I was diagnosed back in Sept, I was not shocked, but certainly alarmed. I had been seeing the urologist for near a decade with BPH, watching my PSA for years, then it decided to rise maybe 24 or 18 months ago. The biopsy revealed the nasty C word but the urologist has been preparing me for the C word and the possibilities for years. Certainly hearing the word then learning you have it are two different things, but it should not be a shock if we have been seeing a Doc for the last many years for testing. A huge disappointment ? sure... I opted for surgery, I'm 69, not 49 , not 59. Age is a major factor. I, like mentioned above , wanted it OUT of me. there is only one way to do that. Additionally, once radiation treatments are selected and begin, we cannot go back to surgery should the need arise. I am not PRO surgery, I am not PRO Robot technology, I am PRO getting rid of Cancer. My decision came from multiple facets, including a couple of friends who had surgery and some who did not have surgery.The ones who did had rather fast recoveries and the ones who didn't had continued visits to the Dr over a few years, one close to 10 years of treatments . He did not qualify for surgery but wished he did. I selected surgery well before I even knew of this forum. This is not a PRO surgery site, not by any stretch, it's an ANTI Cancer site. Each of us are different, we are different ages, we have different life styles, we have different bodies and we have different desires long term, shy of we all wanna live another 10 , 15 years or longer. The first question I asked my urologist before I even talked to a surgeon was , what would you do ? He said, I'm 70, I'de get the dang thing out of me into a trash bucket. We talked several options but for me and my wife, at my age, my health, getting it out of my body was first and foremost if I could somehow make that happen. When we met with the surgeon we discussed several options, he didn't push surgery , he's also an oncologist, he gave me the options and stats which best fit my desire. When I learned that surgery was no longer an option should treatments not be fully successful, thats where my wife and I both said at the same time, Surgery, remove the prostate, remove the cancer if it's possible. Of course many people decide on treatments for various reasons , I seriously doubt anyone chooses surgery because theres a robot guiding the hand of the surgeon. We each have prostate cancer, something we never asked for , it's a very scary time. We make a decision and we go with it. We want it out, gone, cured, call it whatever you want. We need to trust the Dr's 100% and then not second guess. Radiation or surgery may very well be 100% great for one person, but 100% wrong for another. We are all different, we will each heal differently, we will each react to treatments differently. We become stats. Whatever treatment anyone decides to select, I support them 100% . Don't select surgery because I did, select the treatment that best fits your desires and life style over the next many years. best to all t

Posts.Title: How to decide on treatment, facts, and prejudices.

Posts.Content: Jake, glad to hear you made it thru and the catheter is out. By the way , I am not a DR , I just have an opinion here and there. We all react differently and heal differently, so don't be alarmed, you just had major invasive surgery even if we describe it as 'it was nuthin" ! The leaking will be with you for a bit, directly after surgery I had leaking when standing or excessive movement during the day. I was fortunate as I was 100 % dry at night and I was able to start regular peeing soon after surgery but the leaking still occurred. It gradually got better over time, not days but rather weeks. I feel we have to train ourselves with this new phenomenon , sudden movements, getting up from sitting etc... we need to be aware. I believe after maybe 2 months things were noticeably improved. Daily walking with Kegel exercise was a big help. In addition, our daily eating and drinking habits must also change, limited fluids , the type of fluids we take in etc, late in the day and evenings can go a long way towards night time continence. At 6 months now, my daily schedule for peeing is "known". I am at about 3 hours between pee session unless I am drinking coffee ( 2-3 cups each AM) which I am not giving up. I'll learn to deal with it. The leaking is really down to minimal now , even over the last month or two there has been improvement, even with lots of physical activity. I am very lite on fluids though, I drink water but not the whole bottle, I nurse it. I believe after a period of healing ( probably 4,5 or even 6 months) we can self regulate how things go. We can't rush this. We feel great on the outside but our bladder and surrounding area knows something big happened. Just give it time, settle in on what your body is doing, it will get better. Learn how much fluids and what types of fluids you can take without consequence. My first PSA was 3 months post, < 0.1 undetectable, my 2nd PSA is in 2 weeks. regarding ED, same as above, give it time, you had nerves cut on both sides, this may take a while for them to heal and respond. I had nerve sparring on one side and nerves cut on the other side. Currently I have feelings and sensations but nothing to write hoe about,. Viagra ( 100 MG ) is not working for me at this time. I recently had injection therapy with mild success and will continue with this going forward, but it is a long process. Patience is required. A good friend of mine why is also cured of Prostate cancer puts all of this stuff another way...the side effects are what they are and known, but they sure beat the "OTHER SIDE EFFECT" which we can't ever return from, and thats the entire point of Prostate Cancer treatments, get rid of the cancer so we can carry on for another decade or two...or longer. Wishing you the best , rest up, enjoy your life ! t

Posts.Title: 15 day Post-RALP report

Posts.Content: ANWANK , you are both very fortunate to have each other. That in itself is a blessing. I am now 3 months POST surgery . My wife has been with me every step of the way, it's like we both had PC but only one of us needed the surgery. It will take about 6 to 8 weeks of CURE time to get back to normal physical activity, do not let him begin activities too early. The time up to that point is healing and is really required . Don't push it. He may feel like doing workouts but his body will be saying otherwise. I had zero issues with incontinence , but as you know, there is what they call stress incontinence, he will have to learn how to deal with it . It's like a woman sneezing or coughing and they spot their underwear. It is annoying but it can be overcome with time and patience. For someone who is very active it's going to be a learning process and it may take a few months. ED is another thing, just be patient , things should get back to normal in time. Your husband , like most of us here , will notice improvements weekly once the catheter is removed post surgery. I could have easily began some normal activities 3 or 4 weeks out, I had no pains , I felt great, but my body was not ready for activities quite yet. At 10 weeks out I was doing everything I did PRE surgery , but with the activity will come the stress incontinence. At 12 weeks even that is winding down and getting less and less. But you have to be conscious of it . My wife is loving and caring, as you are . I am blessed to have her at my side . No different than you and your husband. We have been together 35 years. two words....patience and time. Just be there for him , stay positive. If you notice improvements, say so. wishing you the best t

Posts.Title: Advice: How to support my partner the most

Posts.Content: As I look forward to Fri ( tomorrow) and the catheter removed, it's easy to reflect back on this past week and even back to Sept with the positive biopsy. And yes, my wife has been with me every step of the way , I think she is more tired than I am. The amount of information we have taken away from this forum from others personal experiences, far exceeds anything I can give back. As we head towards surgery our minds can easily wander aimlessly and then after surgery the same thing. But reading the shared experiences puts much of that in check. Not that we are all going to react and recover the same, but knowing what others experienced and comparing to whats going on with me took a lot of guess work out of the equation during the Post Op recovery. Sure , my post op numbers look good, and that is a welcome relief, but the road ahead still has some obstacles that we will address. I am very grateful to all of those that shared experiences ahead of me as well as the positive support and I will continue to share "my journey" with others behind me. The #1 take away, we are not alone. We are in a common group, one we never expected or wanted to become part of. But yet, here we are. As John 4803 put it so well, we are all new friends. best to all t

Posts.Title: Week 4 post surgery

Posts.Content: DJIN, 10% of the tumor...(sample) not 10% of the prostate, but it was near the apex. The surgical path on the left side was 100% muscle sparring but on the right he cut wide. We knew this was going to be the case well ahead of surgery. In our discussion yesterday, the Surgeon commented that he personally downgraded the G8 to G7 at surgery but the post op path report left it at G8. I asked if this can be opinion based, he said yes, both ways. He also said that Lab reports can many times be very conservative . So G8 it remained. Also discussed was continence vs incontinence, probably the first question from the Doc was, " are you dry at night " answer is yes. I also reported that I can stop the stream and if I think about it before I stand up, I may be able to stop that really annoying leakage. I do kegels every day when I remember, a few times a day. The Doc also wanted to know about BM's, am I regular ? Answer is yes , every morning now just like pre surgery, and I am still taking two Stool Softeners each day and have no plans to stop. The BM thing in his opinion was really quite important for recovery. The Nurse told me that it's not uncommon for some men to have BM difficulty for many weeks post surgery, which presents additional problems. He looked at my incisions, then gently poked the one on the far right side and said, "this one still hurts a little doesn't it " , I said yeah ..when you poke it ! Otherwise the incisions are right on the healing schedule. My wife, ( big mouth) told them I was doing some very mild yard work, we are talking very mild, they told me to stop and wait another 2 or 3 weeks before doing any physical activity at all. Give it the full 6 or 7 weeks. I am on about a 2 hour pee window at night and that was a concern as I am not getting much sleep. This is how I lived for the last 8 years with BPH. He commented that my bladder has shrunk and that in time it will regain some additional size but it will never be like it was when I was 20. He reminded me that I am 69. The good news is that I am feeling the urge and able to get up and get over to the bathroom, I am not wetting and my pads at night are basically dry. During the day, standing is a bit different, I need to learn how to control the leaking which the Doc stated will improve everyday. He had my incontinence predicted at 10% post surgery , he thinks I am less than that and well on my way to near 100% control. . He calls the leakage a different deal, more related to healing post surgery. The body is trying to figure out what to do when I stand up. The kegels are very important with this , the stronger the muscle gets the better leakage control we will have. regarding ED, way too early to tell. Then as stated above, in 3 months we look at the PSA and should expect 0. At the next visit he said we will also review continence and ED for progress. If my progress is good and the PSA is zero, I most likely will not see him for a year , unless I call with concerns. I am still down about 13 pounds from ( Dr requested) when all this started several months back. The good news here is our eating habits have changed significantly, we have added some carbs back to the diet but limited and not everyday. One thing I shared with a friend yesterday, never take a BM or clear urine for granted. Following the appt I actually read the urine sample report, it was good reading, everything negative. Who woulda thought that reading a urine sample report would ever be of interest. So far so good, except for the annoying leaking.... best to all t

Posts.Title: Two days post op

Posts.Content: So I am now 4 weeks post surgery and 18 days post catheter. My post op labs were all negative, the doc said I won the lottery with the "fully contained in the Prostate" report. I was never in any substantial pain and I never really needed any meds. I am doing pretty well with the continence, I was never 100% incontinent,I have never let it all go uncontrollable. I am still leaking a bit when standing but if I think about it I may be able to stop it before standing. At night, I get up every couple of hours with the urge and have no problem getting to the bathroom. I can now shower and dry off without leaking, I can hold it. I hate the leaking, it's a major annoyance. Kegels help. I wasn't expecting anything other than a Q+A and that is what we did, he went over the surgery, the post op lab report and we talked about the future. I have to return in 12 weeks for my first "post non prostate" PSA test, which he firmly believes will be 0. He asked me if I had an erection yet, I said no, but interestingly, I have some weird feelings down there, but I'm not sure what they mean. But then again, he said that if I answered YES he would have been very surprised as this is very early in the recovery process. He was very pleased with the progress as am I. I'm now on the 12 week countdown to hopefully 0 PSA. t

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Actually, the removed prostate is taken to the lab where a pathologist sections it up and pretty much gives an EXACT pathology report (not a mild one) and sends it to the surgeon. This is one of the advantages of surgery because the surgeon/patient then know EXACTLY what was going on within the prostate as compared to the ESTIMATE offered by the clinical report (meaning the biopsy report). yes of course and I didn't mean to imply otherwise . And you are correct, this is one of the major benefits of surgery, we learn EXACTLY where we stand, first hand.

Posts.Title: 4 weeks post RALP, 1st Dr follow up appt today

Posts.Content: All, I know my wife posted a message but I thought I would add some update. this morning is the 3rd morning Post Surgery , which was Tuesday at 1 PM. 2 nights in Hospital , not 1. Home yesterday around 3 pm. Feeling more alert this morning. Drinking a cup of my coffee. Wife is a real trooper,she is as tired as I am. No real pain, no meds needed, just some discomfort on one incision, the larger one on my right side. Its just tight. Taking Tylenol . First night home was awkward because we have the bag to deal with. Other than that not over whelming. Catheter stays in until next Fri, 7 more days. Going into Surgery ( Tues around 1 PM) was very strange, surreal, I was rolled in, I saw what I thought was the robot, I asked a question about it I think someone said yes, then I woke up in recovery. I asked how long I was there and they said a little over an hour. got to room around 7 PM, wife stayed until around 9 ish I think. First night , no issues, slept most of it I think. No pain, just a soar throat from the breathing tube. I do remember telling them in recovery that I had to pee, it just all didn't feel right, they kept telling me that I was peeing, it was the pressure from the catheter in the bladder.Felt very odd at the time but it went away shortly, maybe an hour or two. I remember I told them it felt like I needed to go stand by a tree and pee, it was urgent. 1st morning post, Wed am, they brought me liquid breakfast. I have not had real food now since Sun night. This is now wed AM. No solid food day before. Lots of IV's , I had real bad nausea for most of the day , then it went away. From the anesthesia they said, that stuff easily takes a day or more to exit our body. Started to have gas pains around this same time. They said I can go home once I pass gas and have a BM , for some odd reason I thought I would do that in this same 1st day, not gonna happen. Liquid lunch and liquid dinner. Nasty broth but no appetite anyway. Didn't start to pass gas until very late in the night into the early Am, had a liquid BM around 5 AM. Still no pains. I've been up and walking around the surgical recovery wing since the early afternoon, just real tired. I can get in and out of bed myself just trying to avoid disturbing the right side incision. The soar throat went away by the end of the day. 2nd morning Thanksgiving morning. Brought me real food, make that real fake food . Some sort of imitation pancakes with some other stuff. I ate a bit, drank some bad coffee and now was just pondering the day. Because I passed gas and had the BM they were saying I would go home . No pain, took out one of the IV's ,no meds. Did some walking around, watched some bad TV, waiting on staff Dr to come in which he did around 10 ish, checked my incisions, said they all looked good, answered a few questions, like 6 weeks to full physical recovery, Q and A about the catheter , showers and stuff. released me around 1, left around 2, home by 3. No word on post op labs yet, that will be early next week, Dr said all went well, expecting a good outcome. No pains this morning just trying to seek a routine , was able to lay on my side in bed , cat kept jumping on me. I doubt I will need those pain meds which I have as they told me everyday should get better, not worse. Just the one incision on the right side is stiff, tight, makes ya grimace if you tug it. I'm now counting the night's until next Fri for the Catheter removal 7 more nights. The nursing staff was amazing for my stay, just excellent and very caring, terrific people, I couldn't do what they do. They are a real blessing. So as of right now, I am 65 hours post surgery and I gotta say, you really need 48 hours in the Surgical rehab wing post surgery, if that means 2 nights or even more, fight the boredom , just do it. One extra night in Hospital will be a welcomed relief. I will report my post op labs as soon as I know them, Dr said he did have a slight issue reconnecting my bladder, his issue not mine, thats why 10 total days on catheter. He also said he down graded my G8 to G7 , but I was half out of it when he was talking to me. He did say he had to cut wide on the right, but we knew that going in. The left side was what he termed full sparing. So we'll see. Thx to all. this forum is a very positive place. t

Posts.Content: Darius, interesting and excellent questions. First I would go to a Urologist who is also an Oncologist. Time to exit the family doc. if you haven't already. Go to where you need to be as thats where you are going to end up anyway. I am puzzled a tad by a positive biopsy in Feb of this year and why you have not been to SEE a Urologist. Who did the biopsy ? This is now Nov. You don't need to communicate with a Urologist you need to be in the care of a Urologist. A PSA rising is not a sign of Cancer, it is a sign to be tested for Cancer. Your PSA is still rising, and you have other symptoms, your body is talking to you. STOP whatever you are doing with your family Dr. and get to a seasoned Urologist now. No disrespect implied. Then you can talk treatments that best fit you and your life style. You should address this now. It's not something that should scare you but it should concern you, take the proper action with the proper Dr and things can go very smoothly. I suspect another biopsy is in order to learn whats going on now, a year later, maybe even a cystoscope to check the bladder again. best to you t

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: welcome ! I can only add that it's better to learn early ( now ) if it is indeed PC , a high PSA is not an indicator of PC it is a flag to be checked for PC . We are assuming there is no PSA history over perhaps the last 5 or 6 years ? Even from a GP for a routine physical ? It would certainly be worthwhile to go back and request the records. These are not things we want to guess at, we want to know exactly what the numbers are. As stated, the URO is looking for an identified trend, not necessarily a high number. That being said, those of us who have experienced and been treated for PC, are somewhat familiar with the stats and reported stats. Just for comparison, At our age, 70 ish , the stats say a normal guy may be in the 4 to 4.5 range which can be an increase form 65 or 66 years old. That 4 to 4.5 may stick around for a few years. If there is no history then indeed the biopsy is required. I feel that any URO worth his or her salt would perform a bio regardless with a 9 + PSA. Its twice what the commonly accepted stat is for 70 years old. IF it's UCLA then great, but don't delay, the sooner the better. The great news is regardless, the treatments available or excellent , maybe some daily life altering habits but nonetheless , treatments are excellent with excellent results. early detection with a proactive attitude and plan is the key. Let us know best to you and you husband t

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: Pre Surgery, Pre Cancer, I had been taking Saw Palmetto , 160 MG tablets daily , for 5 or more years to help combat BPH. Did it help,? Can't say , did it hurt ? No. What did it do for me ? I really don't know other than there is some sort of claim that it helps with BPH. My BPH symptoms remained steady for the last 6 or 7 years, weak stream, urge to go every couple of hours, or less. Did Saw Palmetto help with this ? (I'm sitting here shrugging my shoulders) My urologist said "If you think it's helping then by all means keep taking it " , so I did. I did not take the prescribed BPH meds, too many weird side effects for me. That all changed with an increased PSA and a positive biopsy. I am no longer a Saw Palmetto participant.

A PSA rising is not a sign of Cancer, it is a sign to be tested for Cancer. Your PSA is still rising, and you have other symptoms, your body is talking to you. STOP whatever you are doing with your family Dr. and get to a seasoned Urologist now. No disrespect implied. Then you can talk treatments that best fit you and your life style. You should address this now. It's not something that should scare you but it should concern you, take the proper action with the proper Dr and things can go very smoothly. I suspect another biopsy is in order to learn whats going on now, a year later, maybe even a cystoscope to check the bladder again. best to you t

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: J... Thx for posting and I too am you wishing the best . Yes, evil side effects , but none that can't be overcome with patience and perseverance. I feel I was very much like you pre-surgery, I was not looking forward to it but I didn't dwell on it, all of a sudden 11/21 came and went. Like you and your wife, my wife and I just wanted it behind us , we both remained positive. Still are. We didn't tell many people that I had the dreaded C, just a few here and there. Even now, many don't know whats been going on over the last 3 or 4 months. Maybe I'll tell them, maybe I won't. If your Surgeon has prepared you and given you all the necessary up front info, there is no reason to NOT expect your recovery and post stats to be just as predicted. For us, the upcoming surgery was no longer the main event, our minds flew right past the surgery to the post op lab report. That was our focus, the post op path report . Fortunately for me, it was all negative. Even though that was expected and predicted, we still wanted to hear the words and read the report. For us, this was huge. Wearing a Depends for a few months now seemed insignificant in the scheme of things. Before you know it, it will be the 30th and it will be like the whole thing didn't take more than 5 or 10 seconds and you will be on the other side of the slope. I do pray that you have as good a Hospital staff that I did for my two night stay, they were just flat out awesome. We'll talk to you on the other side T

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas, RALP now 4 days away

Posts.Content: murphyj, welcome , sorry to learn of your situation and I totally concur with what Highlander has stated. Biopsy is the only test to confirm PC, as it is the only LAB result based test. MRI, as stated ,can only identify locations to "look and see" , it is not a confirmation. G6 3+3 is known to be an AS monitoring situation especially with only 2 cores positive out of 12. For me personally as a REF point, I had a PSA rise from the 3's to the 4's to 6.5 in 18 months , at age 67. The first biopsy , once I exceeded a PSA of 5, came back two cores positive, G6 3+3 and G8 4+4. both less than 15%. I lost the lottery with that G8. The URO told me that I probably had G6 activity when my PSA was rising and one of them kept growing. Once I moved into the G8 category, treatment of some sort was required. I am now 6 months POST surgery which we opted for. For me, the best opportunity to rid my body of this nasty PC was surgery, so far so good. Remember though, for me, I am not advising anyone to follow my path. If there is any good news at all, it is that the PC has been identified by the biopsy . Many here have gone thru multiple biopsy's with no confirmation, even with a high/rising PSA . While of course this is not actually good news to learn that you have PC , but it is much better to know that it has been detected rather than NOT to have been detected. I personally know a few where it took near two years of testing to confirm PC with both MRI and multiple biopsy's. The earlier we know the better off we are. We have many excellent treatments available for a full cure, once detected early. I suspect that in your situation AS will be the course of action. Stay the course let us know how things are going for you. Wishing you the best t

Posts.Content: Leach , I , like most, used the Mens Depends with an added pad, ( the 52 in a package pads) it may have been overkill but it worked out fine. Very convenient. I think about 8 or 10 weeks I went to a Haynes brief with the same pad and I think at 12 weeks I started using a womans very thin pad , I feel I was fortunate, I was always dry at night and the dripping was getting less and less each week. I'm now at 5 months, I don't use pads anymore , maybe a slight spot the size of a quarter during the day if I am active. It's less than my wife on day to day basis ! Best to you t

Posts.Title: 5 months post surgery update

Posts.Content: welcome ! I can only add that it's better to learn early ( now ) if it is indeed PC , a high PSA is not an indicator of PC it is a flag to be checked for PC . We are assuming there is no PSA history over perhaps the last 5 or 6 years ? Even from a GP for a routine physical ? It would certainly be worthwhile to go back and request the records. These are not things we want to guess at, we want to know exactly what the numbers are. As stated, the URO is looking for an identified trend, not necessarily a high number. That being said, those of us who have experienced and been treated for PC, are somewhat familiar with the stats and reported stats. Just for comparison, At our age, 70 ish , the stats say a normal guy may be in the 4 to 4.5 range which can be an increase form 65 or 66 years old. That 4 to 4.5 may stick around for a few years. If there is no history then indeed the biopsy is required. I feel that any URO worth his or her salt would perform a bio regardless with a 9 + PSA. Its twice what the commonly accepted stat is for 70 years old. IF it's UCLA then great, but don't delay, the sooner the better. The great news is regardless, the treatments available or excellent , maybe some daily life altering habits but nonetheless , treatments are excellent with excellent results. early detection with a proactive attitude and plan is the key. Let us know best to you and you husband t

Posts.Title: Newbie Question

Posts.Content: Interesting read, here is my point of view. I was diagnosed back in Sept, I was not shocked, but certainly alarmed. I had been seeing the urologist for near a decade with BPH, watching my PSA for years, then it decided to rise maybe 24 or 18 months ago. The biopsy revealed the nasty C word but the urologist has been preparing me for the C word and the possibilities for years. Certainly hearing the word then learning you have it are two different things, but it should not be a shock if we have been seeing a Doc for the last many years for testing. A huge disappointment ? sure... I opted for surgery, I'm 69, not 49 , not 59. Age is a major factor. I, like mentioned above , wanted it OUT of me. there is only one way to do that. Additionally, once radiation treatments are selected and begin, we cannot go back to surgery should the need arise. I am not PRO surgery, I am not PRO Robot technology, I am PRO getting rid of Cancer. My decision came from multiple facets, including a couple of friends who had surgery and some who did not have surgery.The ones who did had rather fast recoveries and the ones who didn't had continued visits to the Dr over a few years, one close to 10 years of treatments . He did not qualify for surgery but wished he did. I selected surgery well before I even knew of this forum. This is not a PRO surgery site, not by any stretch, it's an ANTI Cancer site. Each of us are different, we are different ages, we have different life styles, we have different bodies and we have different desires long term, shy of we all wanna live another 10 , 15 years or longer. The first question I asked my urologist before I even talked to a surgeon was , what would you do ? He said, I'm 70, I'de get the dang thing out of me into a trash bucket. We talked several options but for me and my wife, at my age, my health, getting it out of my body was first and foremost if I could somehow make that happen. When we met with the surgeon we discussed several options, he didn't push surgery , he's also an oncologist, he gave me the options and stats which best fit my desire. When I learned that surgery was no longer an option should treatments not be fully successful, thats where my wife and I both said at the same time, Surgery, remove the prostate, remove the cancer if it's possible. Of course many people decide on treatments for various reasons , I seriously doubt anyone chooses surgery because theres a robot guiding the hand of the surgeon. We each have prostate cancer, something we never asked for , it's a very scary time. We make a decision and we go with it. We want it out, gone, cured, call it whatever you want. We need to trust the Dr's 100% and then not second guess. Radiation or surgery may very well be 100% great for one person, but 100% wrong for another. We are all different, we will each heal differently, we will each react to treatments differently. We become stats. Whatever treatment anyone decides to select, I support them 100% . Don't select surgery because I did, select the treatment that best fits your desires and life style over the next many years. best to all t

Posts.Title: 1st Time Poster...

Posts.Content: Surgery was Nov 21, I have a thread running with my updates as well. Today is 8 days since. The Dr called this morning with excellent news, all clear, no evidence of cancer escaping the prostate. Everything is clear including all lymph nodes. Although I don't have a full detailed list of stats to share , the news itself is what we wanted to hear and what the Dr was expecting. He did tell me that the one G8 cell was still being assessed as G8 , so no downgrade. I asked about the PT score, he said PT2 which means the cells were contained in the prostate, organ confined. regarding recovery, all is well, almost feels to well. No pains, no meds, BM's approaching regular, appetite growing , incisions starting to itch. Catheter will be removed Fri, ( 2 days from now) which would be 10 days total. Urine is clear. OF course there are still a few common factors post surgery to deal with , but one step at a time is ok with me. previous post surgery thread https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-RALP-surgery best to all t

Posts.Title: Post Surgery report back tpjames

Posts.Content: All, I know my wife posted a message but I thought I would add some update. this morning is the 3rd morning Post Surgery , which was Tuesday at 1 PM. 2 nights in Hospital , not 1. Home yesterday around 3 pm. Feeling more alert this morning. Drinking a cup of my coffee. Wife is a real trooper,she is as tired as I am. No real pain, no meds needed, just some discomfort on one incision, the larger one on my right side. Its just tight. Taking Tylenol . First night home was awkward because we have the bag to deal with. Other than that not over whelming. Catheter stays in until next Fri, 7 more days. Going into Surgery ( Tues around 1 PM) was very strange, surreal, I was rolled in, I saw what I thought was the robot, I asked a question about it I think someone said yes, then I woke up in recovery. I asked how long I was there and they said a little over an hour. got to room around 7 PM, wife stayed until around 9 ish I think. First night , no issues, slept most of it I think. No pain, just a soar throat from the breathing tube. I do remember telling them in recovery that I had to pee, it just all didn't feel right, they kept telling me that I was peeing, it was the pressure from the catheter in the bladder.Felt very odd at the time but it went away shortly, maybe an hour or two. I remember I told them it felt like I needed to go stand by a tree and pee, it was urgent. 1st morning post, Wed am, they brought me liquid breakfast. I have not had real food now since Sun night. This is now wed AM. No solid food day before. Lots of IV's , I had real bad nausea for most of the day , then it went away. From the anesthesia they said, that stuff easily takes a day or more to exit our body. Started to have gas pains around this same time. They said I can go home once I pass gas and have a BM , for some odd reason I thought I would do that in this same 1st day, not gonna happen. Liquid lunch and liquid dinner. Nasty broth but no appetite anyway. Didn't start to pass gas until very late in the night into the early Am, had a liquid BM around 5 AM. Still no pains. I've been up and walking around the surgical recovery wing since the early afternoon, just real tired. I can get in and out of bed myself just trying to avoid disturbing the right side incision. The soar throat went away by the end of the day. 2nd morning Thanksgiving morning. Brought me real food, make that real fake food . Some sort of imitation pancakes with some other stuff. I ate a bit, drank some bad coffee and now was just pondering the day. Because I passed gas and had the BM they were saying I would go home . No pain, took out one of the IV's ,no meds. Did some walking around, watched some bad TV, waiting on staff Dr to come in which he did around 10 ish, checked my incisions, said they all looked good, answered a few questions, like 6 weeks to full physical recovery, Q and A about the catheter , showers and stuff. released me around 1, left around 2, home by 3. No word on post op labs yet, that will be early next week, Dr said all went well, expecting a good outcome. No pains this morning just trying to seek a routine , was able to lay on my side in bed , cat kept jumping on me. I doubt I will need those pain meds which I have as they told me everyday should get better, not worse. Just the one incision on the right side is stiff, tight, makes ya grimace if you tug it. I'm now counting the night's until next Fri for the Catheter removal 7 more nights. The nursing staff was amazing for my stay, just excellent and very caring, terrific people, I couldn't do what they do. They are a real blessing. So as of right now, I am 65 hours post surgery and I gotta say, you really need 48 hours in the Surgical rehab wing post surgery, if that means 2 nights or even more, fight the boredom , just do it. One extra night in Hospital will be a welcomed relief. I will report my post op labs as soon as I know them, Dr said he did have a slight issue reconnecting my bladder, his issue not mine, thats why 10 total days on catheter. He also said he down graded my G8 to G7 , but I was half out of it when he was talking to me. He did say he had to cut wide on the right, but we knew that going in. The left side was what he termed full sparing. So we'll see. Thx to all. this forum is a very positive place. t

Posts.Title: My Surgery Follow-Up First Post Op PSA

Posts.Content: DJIN, 10% of the tumor...(sample) not 10% of the prostate, but it was near the apex. The surgical path on the left side was 100% muscle sparring but on the right he cut wide. We knew this was going to be the case well ahead of surgery. In our discussion yesterday, the Surgeon commented that he personally downgraded the G8 to G7 at surgery but the post op path report left it at G8. I asked if this can be opinion based, he said yes, both ways. He also said that Lab reports can many times be very conservative . So G8 it remained. Also discussed was continence vs incontinence, probably the first question from the Doc was, " are you dry at night " answer is yes. I also reported that I can stop the stream and if I think about it before I stand up, I may be able to stop that really annoying leakage. I do kegels every day when I remember, a few times a day. The Doc also wanted to know about BM's, am I regular ? Answer is yes , every morning now just like pre surgery, and I am still taking two Stool Softeners each day and have no plans to stop. The BM thing in his opinion was really quite important for recovery. The Nurse told me that it's not uncommon for some men to have BM difficulty for many weeks post surgery, which presents additional problems. He looked at my incisions, then gently poked the one on the far right side and said, "this one still hurts a little doesn't it " , I said yeah ..when you poke it ! Otherwise the incisions are right on the healing schedule. My wife, ( big mouth) told them I was doing some very mild yard work, we are talking very mild, they told me to stop and wait another 2 or 3 weeks before doing any physical activity at all. Give it the full 6 or 7 weeks. I am on about a 2 hour pee window at night and that was a concern as I am not getting much sleep. This is how I lived for the last 8 years with BPH. He commented that my bladder has shrunk and that in time it will regain some additional size but it will never be like it was when I was 20. He reminded me that I am 69. The good news is that I am feeling the urge and able to get up and get over to the bathroom, I am not wetting and my pads at night are basically dry. During the day, standing is a bit different, I need to learn how to control the leaking which the Doc stated will improve everyday. He had my incontinence predicted at 10% post surgery , he thinks I am less than that and well on my way to near 100% control. . He calls the leakage a different deal, more related to healing post surgery. The body is trying to figure out what to do when I stand up. The kegels are very important with this , the stronger the muscle gets the better leakage control we will have. regarding ED, way too early to tell. Then as stated above, in 3 months we look at the PSA and should expect 0. At the next visit he said we will also review continence and ED for progress. If my progress is good and the PSA is zero, I most likely will not see him for a year , unless I call with concerns. I am still down about 13 pounds from ( Dr requested) when all this started several months back. The good news here is our eating habits have changed significantly, we have added some carbs back to the diet but limited and not everyday. One thing I shared with a friend yesterday, never take a BM or clear urine for granted. Following the appt I actually read the urine sample report, it was good reading, everything negative. Who woulda thought that reading a urine sample report would ever be of interest. So far so good, except for the annoying leaking.... best to all t

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic How do surgeon's come up with a G score after the RP? Is it based on their reading of the path report? Good question, I would think that a Surgeon who is very experienced can examine the prostate after the surgery and make a mild determination. Is it worse than I thought or better than I thought ? But I suspect they never argue the final path report. Regardless, the best news in my case was that it was confined, thats what we all hope for and I wish everyone had the same report. t

Posts.Title: 3rd morning post RALP surgery

Posts.Content: well, in many stat camps, after treatment , we have a +/- 15 year survival rate , what if we are 70 and are able to to live past 90 ? Throw in the towel at 85 ? Geesh, did they say what happens to a very healthy 70 year old man who has an un-diagnosed , untreated Gleason 10 that jumps out of the prostate ? do they even make 75 ? Scary report ! I very close friend of mine ( mid 50's) told me a few months ago that his PSA was near 1 after his physical with the family Doc. The family Doc told him that with that low PSA he will never get Prostate cancer. Well, it took me about a millisecond to tell him this... "When I was in my late 50's my PSA was very consistent around 1.2 , when I got closer to 65 it was moving upward into the 2's then the 3's...when I was 68 it was over 4 then over 6...When I was 69 , as you know, I was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer and had surgery". Then I said this.. "Fire your family doctor" ..."today"...

Posts.Title: Looks like old guys over 70 do not have to worry about death from PC

Posts.Content: So I am now 4 weeks post surgery and 18 days post catheter. My post op labs were all negative, the doc said I won the lottery with the "fully contained in the Prostate" report. I was never in any substantial pain and I never really needed any meds. I am doing pretty well with the continence, I was never 100% incontinent,I have never let it all go uncontrollable. I am still leaking a bit when standing but if I think about it I may be able to stop it before standing. At night, I get up every couple of hours with the urge and have no problem getting to the bathroom. I can now shower and dry off without leaking, I can hold it. I hate the leaking, it's a major annoyance. Kegels help. I wasn't expecting anything other than a Q+A and that is what we did, he went over the surgery, the post op lab report and we talked about the future. I have to return in 12 weeks for my first "post non prostate" PSA test, which he firmly believes will be 0. He asked me if I had an erection yet, I said no, but interestingly, I have some weird feelings down there, but I'm not sure what they mean. But then again, he said that if I answered YES he would have been very surprised as this is very early in the recovery process. He was very pleased with the progress as am I. I'm now on the 12 week countdown to hopefully 0 PSA. t

Good question, I would think that a Surgeon who is very experienced can examine the prostate after the surgery and make a mild determination. Is it worse than I thought or better than I thought ? But I suspect they never argue the final path report. Regardless, the best news in my case was that it was confined, thats what we all hope for and I wish everyone had the same report. t

Posts.Title: 4 weeks post RALP, 1st Dr follow up appt today

Posts.Content: As I look forward to Fri ( tomorrow) and the catheter removed, it's easy to reflect back on this past week and even back to Sept with the positive biopsy. And yes, my wife has been with me every step of the way , I think she is more tired than I am. The amount of information we have taken away from this forum from others personal experiences, far exceeds anything I can give back. As we head towards surgery our minds can easily wander aimlessly and then after surgery the same thing. But reading the shared experiences puts much of that in check. Not that we are all going to react and recover the same, but knowing what others experienced and comparing to whats going on with me took a lot of guess work out of the equation during the Post Op recovery. Sure , my post op numbers look good, and that is a welcome relief, but the road ahead still has some obstacles that we will address. I am very grateful to all of those that shared experiences ahead of me as well as the positive support and I will continue to share "my journey" with others behind me. The #1 take away, we are not alone. We are in a common group, one we never expected or wanted to become part of. But yet, here we are. As John 4803 put it so well, we are all new friends. best to all t

Posts.Title: Post Surgery report back tpjames

Posts.Content: Surgery was Nov 21, I have a thread running with my updates as well. Today is 8 days since. The Dr called this morning with excellent news, all clear, no evidence of cancer escaping the prostate. Everything is clear including all lymph nodes. Although I don't have a full detailed list of stats to share , the news itself is what we wanted to hear and what the Dr was expecting. He did tell me that the one G8 cell was still being assessed as G8 , so no downgrade. I asked about the PT score, he said PT2 which means the cells were contained in the prostate, organ confined. regarding recovery, all is well, almost feels to well. No pains, no meds, BM's approaching regular, appetite growing , incisions starting to itch. Catheter will be removed Fri, ( 2 days from now) which would be 10 days total. Urine is clear. OF course there are still a few common factors post surgery to deal with , but one step at a time is ok with me. previous post surgery thread https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-RALP-surgery best to all t

Posts.Title: Highly Experienced Surgeon Claims Significant DOWNGRADES After RP

Posts.Content: murphyj, welcome , sorry to learn of your situation and I totally concur with what Highlander has stated. Biopsy is the only test to confirm PC, as it is the only LAB result based test. MRI, as stated ,can only identify locations to "look and see" , it is not a confirmation. G6 3+3 is known to be an AS monitoring situation especially with only 2 cores positive out of 12. For me personally as a REF point, I had a PSA rise from the 3's to the 4's to 6.5 in 18 months , at age 67. The first biopsy , once I exceeded a PSA of 5, came back two cores positive, G6 3+3 and G8 4+4. both less than 15%. I lost the lottery with that G8. The URO told me that I probably had G6 activity when my PSA was rising and one of them kept growing. Once I moved into the G8 category, treatment of some sort was required. I am now 6 months POST surgery which we opted for. For me, the best opportunity to rid my body of this nasty PC was surgery, so far so good. Remember though, for me, I am not advising anyone to follow my path. If there is any good news at all, it is that the PC has been identified by the biopsy . Many here have gone thru multiple biopsy's with no confirmation, even with a high/rising PSA . While of course this is not actually good news to learn that you have PC , but it is much better to know that it has been detected rather than NOT to have been detected. I personally know a few where it took near two years of testing to confirm PC with both MRI and multiple biopsy's. The earlier we know the better off we are. We have many excellent treatments available for a full cure, once detected early. I suspect that in your situation AS will be the course of action. Stay the course let us know how things are going for you. Wishing you the best t

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Darius, interesting and excellent questions. First I would go to a Urologist who is also an Oncologist. Time to exit the family doc. if you haven't already. Go to where you need to be as thats where you are going to end up anyway. I am puzzled a tad by a positive biopsy in Feb of this year and why you have not been to SEE a Urologist. Who did the biopsy ? This is now Nov. You don't need to communicate with a Urologist you need to be in the care of a Urologist. A PSA rising is not a sign of Cancer, it is a sign to be tested for Cancer. Your PSA is still rising, and you have other symptoms, your body is talking to you. STOP whatever you are doing with your family Dr. and get to a seasoned Urologist now. No disrespect implied. Then you can talk treatments that best fit you and your life style. You should address this now. It's not something that should scare you but it should concern you, take the proper action with the proper Dr and things can go very smoothly. I suspect another biopsy is in order to learn whats going on now, a year later, maybe even a cystoscope to check the bladder again. best to you t

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: J... Thx for posting and I too am you wishing the best . Yes, evil side effects , but none that can't be overcome with patience and perseverance. I feel I was very much like you pre-surgery, I was not looking forward to it but I didn't dwell on it, all of a sudden 11/21 came and went. Like you and your wife, my wife and I just wanted it behind us , we both remained positive. Still are. We didn't tell many people that I had the dreaded C, just a few here and there. Even now, many don't know whats been going on over the last 3 or 4 months. Maybe I'll tell them, maybe I won't. If your Surgeon has prepared you and given you all the necessary up front info, there is no reason to NOT expect your recovery and post stats to be just as predicted. For us, the upcoming surgery was no longer the main event, our minds flew right past the surgery to the post op lab report. That was our focus, the post op path report . Fortunately for me, it was all negative. Even though that was expected and predicted, we still wanted to hear the words and read the report. For us, this was huge. Wearing a Depends for a few months now seemed insignificant in the scheme of things. Before you know it, it will be the 30th and it will be like the whole thing didn't take more than 5 or 10 seconds and you will be on the other side of the slope. I do pray that you have as good a Hospital staff that I did for my two night stay, they were just flat out awesome. We'll talk to you on the other side T

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Tim, thx for the report. Sounds like you are improving nicely ! The wetting at night is indeed incontinence but the leaking during the day while walking or coughing etc may not be considered incontinent. As it was explained to me it is more related to physical muscle control which we never had to do before. This is typical and normal following surgery and from what I am learning may last as long as a year to some degree. Regarding your night time control, thats great news as that is really what the Dr's are looking for, control at night while sleeping, not emptying the bladder uncontrolled. DRY at night. Perhaps the medical term is still incontinence but what your are experiencing is very common and part of our internal healing process as well as our "new" awareness control. Our wives cough and sneeze, and drop a spot of pee...thats what woman do . Now, we as men following surgery may do the same thing as we now use the same muscles that our wives do. Now this sounds nasty, but my wife reminded me that she sometimes changes underwear a couple of times a day and has for her entire life. Coughing, sneezing, laughing....I don't know what to call that. I am now 6 weeks post surgery, for me the good news is I never wet at night or emptied my bladder uncontrolled. In the early days following catheter removal when I had the urge , I only had moments to get to the bathroom or I would not be able to maintain control. Now 6 weeks later this is not an issue. Regarding leaking or small drips. YES , if I stand quickly or do something strenuous , I will leak. It's getting better but it's still an annoyance. If I think about it before I make a "move" I may be able to prevent it. Now I'm not a Dr but this , according to those who I have asked , they say this is not incontinence but rather weak muscles and awareness. It's very common and can last a good while, maybe a year. Regular Kegels do indeed help with this. My last visit to the Dr two weeks ago he really only cared about being dry at night, the slight leaking/dripping was an artifact of learning how to control with just our rear muscles. He expects it to diminish over the following months as I learn how to use my muscles. KEGELS is the key here. If you are not fully emptying your bladder uncontrolled, you are not incontinent. If you can stop the stream, hold it and get to the bathroom, you are on the other side of the curve. That annoying leaking thing, well, we have to learn how to work around it . Some of us will gain control of it earlier than others. We now have to be aware, something we never had to do before. My wife and I had lunch with a good friend and his wife yesterday, he had surgery 1 year ago. We talked a little about the leaking and dripping . His wife put it into perspective in a very short sentence. "We as woman have been doing that our whole lives" ! Kinda put it into perspective. My friend , over a year now, does have a drip or two if he does something strenuous or physical . It's not an everyday occurrence but it is still on the radar.

Posts.Title: 5 months post-surgery continence status

Posts.Content: Jeff, report is really not so bad. regarding incontinence, when I first got the catheter out I literally had moments to get to the bathroom from the urge. While I didn't have any total wetting issues ( unloading the bladder) I had leakage and still do. This is 7 weeks now. The leakage is still more of an annoyance than anything. Not at night in bed and not while sitting , but rather when I stand up or start to move around. But It's getting better each week . I can tell the difference. I would say it's too early to gauge your "system performance" , especially so close to the catheter being removed. Give it a few weeks before you start to take notes, Mr Catheter and Mr Bladder are not friends and MR Bladder may take some time to get over the invasion. I believe the first reference we are looking for is how we are doing at night ? Are you getting the urge and attempt to get to the bathroom in time or does the bladder just empty itself with no warning , no feeling, it just happens. ? One is incontinence the other is just really weak muscle control. We know we gotta hold it but can't, YET. Kegels really do help with this, don't ignore them. You could not do them with a catheter. Now you can. Personally I have found for me ,that when I walk ( at least 1/2 to 1 mile a day ) doing the kegels at this time is the best. I can concentrate on the squeeze and hold . This is real world . Getting up and moving around is really the only time I have any undesired annoying leakage. Although I am 7 weeks post surgery I am 6 weeks post catheter. It just takes time and understanding how to deal with our new circumstances. Our new life, it seems we have to plan our moves and prepare for them. I have also come to learn that while wearing either the Depends or Briefs ( with a pad) I try to keep the little fella pointed UP , this helps immensely. This week I graduated from Depends to Haynes Briefs. I still use the pads and my wife gave me some of her thin pads to use as a side shield , as a precaution. It's all a learning and experimenting game until I can gain full control of the annoying leaking thing. Learn what works best. My wife reminds me that she "spots" everyday and has for her entire life. All woman do. They learn to live with it, now we have to as well. Of course I am not talking about excessive leakage but the occasional spotting. Give it some time, things will improve, we can't rush this stuff. Wish we could. I suspect that over the next 4 or 5 weeks you will report that things have really improved. best to you t

I have also come to learn that while wearing either the Depends or Briefs ( with a pad) I try to keep the little fella pointed UP , this helps immensely. This week I graduated from Depends to Haynes Briefs. I still use the pads and my wife gave me some of her thin pads to use as a side shield , as a precaution. It's all a learning and experimenting game until I can gain full control of the annoying leaking thing. Learn what works best. My wife reminds me that she "spots" everyday and has for her entire life. All woman do. They learn to live with it, now we have to as well. Of course I am not talking about excessive leakage but the occasional spotting. Give it some time, things will improve, we can't rush this stuff. Wish we could. I suspect that over the next 4 or 5 weeks you will report that things have really improved. best to you t

Posts.Title: Day 11, post RALP with pathologic data

Posts.Content: GMJJ, it appears you are well within the typical and normal time window. For me personally, the journey towards treatment started late July of this year with the surgery scheduled for next week. Basically 4 months ,approx 13 weeks from the PSA test results that started the train rolling. Biopsy, consult office visits, Cystascope , a few Pre-ops , CT scans, Kegel appt, etc.. to surgery. personally, I had more activity this week with appts than at any other time, 4 different appts, 1 week before surgery. I am also wearing a wrist band which cannot be removed , it CLEARS me for surgery. Gleason 6, 7 and 8 certainly requires a treatment, you are on the right path. One thing I can add, once you make a decision as to which treatment is best , don't look back, go forward, wait it out , This forum is a fine place to visit and is very positive. Forget the google searches, they will just add stress and cause you to second guess yourself. Best to you and your husband. t

Posts.Title: Very Best Holiday Wishes

Posts.Content: garrjim, welcome. I am one of your local friends and glad to be of support in any way that I can . Regardless of which treatment you select, the good news is you will begin a treatment plan and the cure. As you know, my situation was PSA rising over an 18 month period, 3.4 > 4.4 > 6.4. My first biopsy showed 2 spots out of 12, but there were probably more , 1/Gleason 6 and 1/ Gleason 8. The G8 was the deal killer in my case. My stats are listed below in my signature. I opted for surgery , no regrets. YES some side effects which are now going away quickly. I had no incontinence to speak of and the ED thing is being addressed now, 3 months post surgery. My physical recovery (incisions) was really right at 6 weeks but I felt like I could have gone back to regular physical activities earlier, I had no pains whatsoever. I was told 6 weeks, NOT LESS ! I had the catheter for 10 days so I limited myself to the house for those 10 days. Once the catheter was removed I started getting back to regular life, even went back to the first gig 4 weeks post surgery. We have the same Dr so I can say, based on my experiences, he was spot on every step of the way. Before surgery and after. He can be a tad dry and very direct, but we are not looking for a social director, we are wanting a Dr who is 100% focused on the task at hand. IF you can, go up to SETTINGS at the top right, edit your signature with your stats so that those replying can do an apples to apples comparison. We have tons of experience here and we are now part of an elite group, even though we didn't plan it. stay the course, stay in touch , you know where I am. t

Posts.Title: Catheter Out and Pathology Report

Posts.Content: Surgery Nov 21, 2017. Just had the 2nd post surgery PSA, came back undetectable. Next PSA Sept /Oct. Never really had an issue with incontinence from the get go, lucky I guess . Day time stress leakage is really at a minimum, not zero but dang close, and thats with activity. A small spot now and then. I don't actually worry about what I eat or drink , I don't even think about it. I am a 2 to 3 cups of coffee each morning person so perhaps thats a contributing factor. ED , still in repair. We are trying a few different things to wake it up, the injections indeed work but I would prefer other methods, such as the troche viagra tabs. It's what we all call "trial" phase. All under Docs approvals of course. It may very well take another few moths or so, but it's a process. One thing I have learned from all players is we don't want to let it sit idle for a year or two without trying some form of treatments, even if they re not successful at first. It's a process. No surgery regrets whatsoever, my life is literally back on track . I now have 3 close friends going thru this madness since my surgery last Nov , one has chosen HIFU and the other two radiation. I pray they all have the same zero C results that I have. best to all t

Posts.Title: Post Surgery Follow-Up - Unexpected News!

Posts.Content: Mikesimm, thx for your update and for sharing. Sorry to read about your pains and meds. It seems that my post catheter experiences are tracking yours, without the pain. My first night home post catheter I thought something was wrong , but of course it was not. I was expecting my bladder to fill and I would have the urge to "go", but that never happened. It wasn't until the morning that I realized that I really had been "going" pretty much all the time by leaking small amounts throughout the afternoon and evening. My bladder was empty. I called the night support team early in the evening and they told me to drink more fluids and If I had the urge to go and couldn't , get over to the ER right away for a bladder scan. I think that both that support Dr and I missed that I had been passing urine all afternoon and that my bladder was indeed empty. I probably didn't give them the proper details. I am now just 2 days post catheter and it appears that while laying down in bed or sitting , there is a small amount of "going" , not much, minimal. But when I stand and go to the toilet, I am emptying the bladder. It will empty on its own so I better be prepared . The first night home I was pretty concerned, I thought I would fill the bladder and feel the urge to go, that didn't happen. It's still not happening but I can tell something is going on. I feel some pressure. Last night my wife asked me why I am getting up a few times, I just told her that I am trying to learn what the heck is going on. I'm trying to get a reference. I don't have any pains , it's more discomfort, some burning sensation. I am taking the meds for the spasms, heck why not. At this point, I am not even trying to stop the stream , but I think I can, to some degree. If I try a firm kegel squeeze my incisions pull so it's way too early to start that stuff with the tightest squeeze . I am starting mild squeezes though just to get into the routine. First things first, my follow up is in 3 weeks so we'll see if there is any progress by that time. This whole ordeal really is a take it slow, one thing at a time process that cannot be rushed along. It's so darn foreign , how would we know how to react to this stuff without others sharing ? We wouldn't. I was a baby and pee'd my pants, then went the next 65 years without peeing my pants, now I'm peeing my pants again. Hopefully it won't be long term. Best to you in your recovery, very grateful for your sharing and I expect many others are as well. t
